taxonomicNotes:
Only the species-level entry Echinocereus chisoensis appears in the 1994 and 1999 Kartesz lists for North America north of Mexico. These lists do not mention typical varieties when only the typical variety occurs within the geographical territory of the checklist, and since only Echinocereus chisoensis var. chisoensis is known to occur in the U.S. (confirmed by John Kartesz to Larry Morse 25 Nov 1999), only the species is listed in the synthesis. The U.S. FWS has designated threatened status under the U.S. Endangered Species Act for E. chisoensis var. chisoensis only. Jackie Poole mentioned an additional variety of E. chisoensis occurring in Mexico, E. chisoensis var. fobeanus (pers. comm. to M. Martinez, July 1994, Poole et al. 2007, Anderson 2001).  Spelling is Echinocereus chisosensis in Flora of North America Editorial Committee (2003), and it is evident that Flora North America does not recognize varieties of E. chisosensis as they mention the 'fobeanus' as a species, Echinocereus foebeanus [sic].

Hunt et al. (2006) recognize two subspecies, the nominate and subsp. fobeanus (Oehme) N.P.Taylor.

Published in the journal Succulenta, 71e(6): 253-255, December, 1992. Accepted by Kartesz (1999). According to Jim Morefield (May 2001), "the descriptions and circumscriptions of S. blainei, S. nyensis, and S. schlesseri are highly inconsistent within and among the recent treatments, suggesting that Heil, Porter, Hochstaetter, and/or Welsh remain confused as to the similarities and differences between these taxa." The Nevada Natural Heritage Program will treat all three as distinct until the confusion can be sorted out.

Eleocharis palustris falls within a taxonomically difficult group including E. oxylepis, E. mamillata and E. uniglumis (Tutin et al. 1980) which would benefit from further investigation. A number of sub-specific taxa have been recognised within this species and two, ssp. vulgaris and ssp. palustris, are widely accepted.

The Yemen population of E. palustris is rather isolated and most collections made [..] are of a form with a rather large lower glume which partly encircles the spikelet, thus showing some approach to the European E. uniglumis (Link) Schult. One collection [..] from between Yarim and Radmah is remarkable for its very large spikelets but the nuts are similar to the more common form. The Yemen plant needs careful investigation and it is likely that one or more distinct varieties can be described (Wood 1997).

P. arundinacea includes a variety of taxa, including ssp. rotgesii which is endemic to Corsica, some authors treat this taxon as a species in which case it would probably be considered to be of conservation concern.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. A. aequalis has been shown to hybridise with A. geniculatus (A. ×haussknechtianus Asch. & Graebn.) which occurs fairly frequently in areas of sympatry but is not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

The only taxonomic issue associated with this name is P. juzepczukii P.I. Dorof. & Tzvelev , which Wiegleb and Kaplan (1998) treat as a synonym but is accepted by the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010).

P. perfoliatus has been shown to hybridize with the following European taxa: P. alpinus (P. × prussicus Hagstr.), P. crispus (P. ×cooperi (Fryer) Fryer), P. gramineus (P. × nitens Weber), P. lucens (P. ×salicifolius Wolfg. in Schult. & Schult.), P. praelongus (P. ×cognatus Asch. & Graebn.), P. pusillus (P. × mysticus Morong) and P. schweinfurthii (P. × vaginans (Bojer ex A. Benn.) Hagstr.).
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
Until recently, other taxa were included within the concept of B. maritimus; this obscures the limits of its distribution and may obscure population trends.

Tzvelev (2006) notes that "sometimes three varieties are identified under this species: var. pectinatus Wallr. with bracts as long as or slightly longer than flowers; var. intermedium with bracts almost 3 times as long as flowers; and var. verticillatum with bracts almost 10 times as long as flowers".

A portion of the genus Polygonum was separated as Persicaria leaving only members of the Polygonum aviculare group in the original genus. Whilst generally widely accepted, IPNI (for example) appears to retain Polygonum as the correct genus for this species, under which name it would be P. lapathifolium L. TROPICOS cites Polygonum lapathifolium var. lapathifolium as the accepted name. P. lapathifolium is a very variable taxon, to the extent that Tela Botanica lists 43 sub-specific taxa, but IPNI and TROPICOS list only between 10 and 20. Hybrids have been reported between this taxon and other Persicaria species, but reliable evidence is sparse; as suggested by Flora Nordica hybridisation is likely to be rare and is unlikely to affect the red list assessment. In the Arabian Peninsula, it appears likely that the treatment of taxa such as P. lapathifolia and P. persicaria is not consistent throughout the region.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

"V.A. Martynenk’s reports about this species for the Timan tundra and vicinity of Arkhangelsk are very doubtful. A deepwater ecoform with erect and not creeping stems on the bottom of the water body and larger semitransparent leaves resembling the submerged leaves of water starwort was described under the name E. triandra var. callitricheoides W. Nyl." (Tzvelev 2006). "Tall plants with long internodes and long narrow, lanceolate-oblong, flaccid leaves, with apical parts of the shoot and branches not rooted but upright, and often with flowers in both leaf axils of a node, have been distinguished as E. callitrichoides. Such plants often grow in sheltered places on very soft oozy bottoms; they are modifications and do not deserve taxonomic recognition" (Preston 2010).
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

N. pumila is known to hybridise with N. lutea (N. ×spenneriana Gaudin) and although this hybrid is not infrequent where the ranges of the parents overlap, it is not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.

There are no significant taxonomic issues affecting this name. P. friesii is known to hybridise with P. crispus (P. ×lintonii Fryer) and P. acutifolius (P. ×pseudofriesii Dandy et G.Taylor) in Europe. These hybrids are uncommon and are unlikely to affect either the status of the species or this evaluation.

An accepted synonym is Veronica chillensis Kunth.
Its common name is Necklace Weed.
Synomyn is Najas indica (Willdenow) Chamisso var. gracillima A. Braun ex Engelm.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

This is a morphologically variable species with many synonyms. Some authors distinguish subsp. raynalii (Schuyler) Beentje. The difference between the subspecies was based mainly on the waviness of the nutlet. Subsp. erectus differs mainly from subsp. raynalii in lacking the very pronounced frill on the nutlet.

Vigna luteola (Jacq.) Benth. is a genepool tertiary wild relative of both Bambara Groundnut [Vigna subterranea (L.) Verdc. var. subterranea (L.) Verdc.] and Cowpea [Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp. var. unguiculata (L.) Walp.]. The species is also classified in Taxon Group 2 of Bambara Groundnut and Taxon Group 3 of Cowpea (Vincent et al. 2013), following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

Some authorities treat Schoenoplectus tabernaemontani as a subspecies of S. lacustris (e.g., Sell and Murrell 1996, Castroviejo et al. 2008) while others (such as TROPICOS) maintain it within Scirpus. In Euro-Med checklist this is a synony of S. lacustris subsp. glaucus (Sm.) Bech (Euro+Med PlantBase). 

Schoenoplectus tabernaemontani hybridises with S. triqueter (L.) Palla and is reported to hybridise with S. lacustris, however the latter is unproven whilst the former is not sufficiently frequent to affect the Red List assessment for this species (Jermy et al. 2007).

A portion of the genus Polygonum was separated as Persicaria leaving only members of the Polygonum aviculare group in the original genus. Whilst generally widely accepted, IPNI and TROPICOS (for example) appear to retain Polygonum as the correct genus for this species, under which name it would be P. persicaria L. Hybrids have been reported between this taxon and other Persicaria species, but reliable evidence is sparse; as suggested by Jonsell et al. (2000) hybridisation is likely to be rare and is unlikely to affect the red list assessment. In the Arabian Peninsula, it appears likely that the treatment of taxa such as P. lapathifolia and P. persicaria is not consistent throughout the region.

Following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), V. lathyroides L. is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 3) of Narbon Bean (V. narbonensis L.), Hungarian Vetch (V. pannonica Crantz) and Common Vetch (V. sativa L.) (Maxted 1993, 1995). It is also a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of One-flowered Vetch (V. articulata Hornem.) and Bitter Vetch (V. ervilia (L.) Willd.), and a tertiary wild relative of Faba Bean (V. faba L.) (Pickersgill et al. 1983).
This species is not found in India (Kew World Plant Database)

Studies on population genetics and phylogeny of the complex Sclerocactus glaucus showed that S. brevispinus and S. wetlandicus are different at the species rank (Heil and Porter 1994, Porter et al. 2000). Therefore, S. brevispinus is here assessed as a separate species.
Acer platanoides subsp. turkestanicum is not included here as it is cosnidered valid at species level: Acer turkestanicum.

Infrataxa recognized:
- Acer saccharum Marshall subsp. saccharum
- Acer saccharum subsp. ozarkense Murray
- Acer saccharum var. rugelii (Pax) Rehder
- Acer saccharum var. schneckii Rehder.
There are numerous synonyms as listed on Plant List http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-117615

Difficulty arises in identifying Quercus fusiformis from Q. virginiana. However, this is only true for Q. fusiformis in the US. The issue is reflected in taxonomic treatments, including reducing Q. fusiformis to varietal rank under Q. virginiana when Q. fusiformis in northeastern Mexico is amply distinct from Q. virginiana.
Jean Louis Helardot does not approve the species, listing Q. virginiana as a synonym.
None.

Carpinus caroliniana consists of two rather well-marked geographical races, treated here as subspecies. These hybridize or intergrade in a band extending from Long Island along the Atlantic coast through coastal Virginia and North Carolina, and then westward in northern South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, and Louisiana. Plants with intermediate features are also found throughout the highlands of Missouri and Arkansas. J. J. Furlow (1987b) has described the variation of this complex in detail.

The Flora of North America in their treatment of Ostrya chisosensis states that this species appears to be related to O. knowltonii.  NatureServe is using a place holder name, Ostrya virginiana var. 1 awaiting the publication of Ostrya virginiana var. chisosensis _____.  ITIS (2013) relates that the trinomial Ostrya virginiana var. chisosensis (Correll) Henrickson ined. was apparently never published.

Ostrya chisosensis Correll is the accepted name. (PLANTS, 2013; Plant List, 2013, Tropicos, 2013).

Ashburner and McAllister (2013) have combined Betula nana ssp. exilis into Betula glandulosa. The authors state “We interpret the material traditionally referred to B. nana ssp. exilis as dwarf, mainly more northern, variants of B. glandulosa”. This assessment follows the taxonomy of Ashburner and McAllister (2013).

Betula kenaica is said to differ from B. papyrifera primarily in its smaller stature and in its smaller, blunter-tipped, more coarsely and regularly serrate leaves. It is best considered a westward extension of B. papyrifera into southern Alaska, perhaps affected by introgression from B. pendula ssp. mandshurica.
In North America (and elsewhere) this taxon is widely known as Alnus viridis, a recent publication (Chery 2015) outlines that Alnus alnobetula (Ehrh.) K.Koch is the accepted name.
None.
Ashburner and McAllister (2013) have placed Betula nana ssp. exilis in synonymy with Betula glandulosa.

Alnus serrulata was erroneously called A . rugosa in a number of earlier floristic works (J. K. Small 1903, 1933; N. L. Britton and A. Brown 1896, 1913; B. L. Robinson and M. L. Fernald 1908), and the mistake was perpetuated in both editions of Flora Europaea (T. G. Tutin et al. 1964-1980, vol. 1; 1993+, vol. 1).

Material from the Florida keys was previously considered synonyms with O. triacantha but phylogenetical and morphological analysis separate Floridian material as a different species (O. abjecta) (Majure pers. comm. 2011).
This species was previously thought of as Q. imbricaria (Shingle Oak), but further investigation by Duncan showed them to represent an unnamed species that he described as Q. oglethorpensis.

Furlow (1979) published, “The systematics of the American species of Alnus (Betulaceae)" in Rhodora.  Furlow 1997 followed the taxonomy presented in his 1979 paper in his treatment of Alnus in the Flora of North America recognizing Alnus maritima as a taxon with no infraspecific taxa recognized.  Schrader and Grove (2002, 2004) made the case for recognizing three disjunct populations of A. maritima as three separate taxa; A. maritima subsp. maritima (Delmarva Peninsula, Delaware and Maryland); A. maritima subsp. georgiensis Schrader & Graves (Bartow County, Georgia); and, A. maritima subsp. oklahomensis Schrader & Graves (south-central Oklahoma).  Gibson et al. (2008) compared the genetic diversity of the three disjunct populations of A. maritima against the genetic diversity of A. serrulata.  Their findings and conclusions were consistent with the genetic work of Schrader and Graves (2004). Research using microsatellites (Jones and Gibson 2011, Jones, 2013) supported the previous taxonomic conclusions that A. maritima is composed of three geographically disjunct subspecies, subsp. maritima, subsp. georgiensis, and subsp. oklahomensis. NatureServe (2013) last reviewed the conservation status of A. maritima in 2011. NatureServe recognizes all three subspecies of A. maritima; subspecies maritima, georgiensis, and oklahomensis.
Data accumulated by Stoynoff and Hess (1990) support the contention that the taxon is a species and not a variety of Q. shumardii.

Trees from the extremes of the distribution in Europe (Betula pendula), northeast Asia and Japan and western North America (B. platyphylla, B. mandshurica, B. neoalaskana) and southwest China and Tibet (B. szechuanica) look different and can be distinguished from one another. However, when the whole continuous geographical range of diploid silver birches is considered, all those named as species intergrade in geographically intervening areas.

It is thought to be best divided into three subspecies, ssp. pendula in Europe and eastwards to central Asia, ssp. mandshurica in eastern Asia and western North America and ssp. szechuanica in western China from Qinghai and Gansu to Yunnan and southeast Xizang.

Betula platyphylla has been described as a separate species, representing birches from Mongolia east of the Altai and into western and northeastern China but it is thought the two are synonymous. Betula oycoviensis previously listed as threatened is a form of B. pendula. Betula pendula ssp. font-queri and B. pendula ssp. parvibracteata, previously listed as threatened are thought to be only minor variants of B. pendula. Betula szaferi, described previously as Extinct in the Wild, is now considered a weak-growing, precociously and heavily fruiting form of B. pendula, due to the presence of a mutant gene.
Alnus glutinosa has been called A. vulgaris Hill in some older literature, however, that name was not validly published (Furlow 1997).

Sheviak and Bowles (1986) described Platanthera praeclara by dividing Platanthera leucophaea into two separate morphological species differing significantly in pollination mechanisms and in geographic distribution.  The original name P. leucophaea was retained for the species occupying the upper Mississippi River drainage and the Great Lakes region in an area corresponding to the prairie peninsula.  The species inhabiting the prairies of the Missouri River drainage (west of Mississippi River) - the center of the tallgrass prairie formation - was named P. praeclara.

There are over 50 synonyms for Galanthus nivalis and this is due to several reasons: it is a variable species and throughout its distribution a number of taxa have been named in an attempt to record this variation; because of its long history in cultivation, a large number of taxa and cultivars have been recognised, leading to an even greater proliferation of names; and before many other species had been described, most Galanthus were referred to or associated with G. nivalis, probably because it was the best known and most ubiquitous species (Davis 1999).

J. articulatus is known to hybridise with J. acutiflorus (J. ×surrejanus Druce ex Stace & Lambinon), it is not clear to what extent the hybrid may have replaced J. articulatus throughout much of the United Kingdom.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
The taxonomy of Ruppia is not completely clear and there are some anomalous populations (e.g. in western Ireland) which do not conform well to described taxa.
The hybrid with N. candida (N. ×sundvikii Hiit.) is occasional, usually in the presence of both parents (Tzvelev 1996).
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name, although numerous varieties and forms have been described. No hybrids with this species are reliably reported.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. The species has been shown to hybridise with S. angustifolium (S. ×diversifolium Graebner) and S. gramineum (S.×speirocephalum Neuman in C.J. Hartman). Although these hybrids may be common, they are not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.

Landolt (1986) states that Lemna perpusilla is endemic to North America and all other records should be attributed to L. aequinoctalis, however Landolt lists no specimens of either species from the Arabian Peninsula, likewise the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (The Trustees of the Royal Botanic Garden, Kew 2012) does. Unless the converse can be demonstrated, this species should not be considered to occur in the Arabian Peninsula. Records of this L. perpusilla and L. aequinoctalis are probably misidentified L. minor.

Three varieties are recognised, var. bogneri which is endemic to Sarawak, var. ciliata occurs throughout the range of the species, var. latifolia is known from a number of localities throughout SE Asia  and sometimes occurs in mixed populations with var. ciliata.

According to Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew WCSPF (World Checklist of Selected Plant Families), this genus belongs to the Araceae Family.

This species may be easily confused with Spirodela polyrhiza.

This species was first observed in the1950s by Phillips (1960) when he misidentified this species as H. baillonis. It was then collected in 1980 and described as a new species (Eiseman and McMillan 1980). There is some controversy with this species in that genetic analysis showed that H. johnsonii is genetically very similar to H. ovalis, which is an Indo-Pacific species (Waycott et al. 2006, Short et al. 2010), suggesting that H. johnsonii may be an introduced representative of H. ovalis, a concept strengthened by the fact that only female plants have been found.

(Creed and Samper-Villarreal, 2019). However, there is no taxonomic uncertainty regarding the identity of either one of these species (Kuo, 2020). Both species have erect shoots with two scales at the base and two more approximately halfway the stem, with two (H. baillonii) or 3-4 (H. engelmannii) pairs of leaves in a pseudo-whorl at the top. Leaf size and morphology differ perceptibly between the species (Den Hartog, 1970).
Halophila hawaiiana is a member of the Halophila ovalis complex, and is under taxonomic review.
This species has been reclassified as Nanozostera (Tomlinson and Posluzny 2001), although here it is retained in the genus Zostera.
This species has often been confused with Halophila ovalis. Halophila decipiens is monoecious, has serrate leaf tips and hairs on both sides of its leaves.

Halodule wrightii is a well established species. However, the taxonomy of the other species of Halodule in the Atlantic is less certain (Larkum et al. 2006) and there are questions about its taxonomy in the Indo-Pacific as well (Green and Short 2003).
Zostera pacifica is a newly resurrected species based on genetic studies in the Channel Is., California, USA.
Valid name of the species is Kyllinga tenuifolia Steud.
The synonym Mariscus cyperoides, sometime considered the senior name, is considered invalid by Tropicos (Missouri Botanical Garden 2021).
Eleusine indica (L.) Gaertn. is a primary crop wild relative of Finger Millet E. coracana (L.) Gaertn. (Vincent et al., 2013)
A taxon which is sometimes included in the wider concept of A. koa A.Gray (also called Racosperma koa (A.Gray) Pedley). It is treated as a separate species here.
Recent taxonomic research has split H. arbuscula into two separate species: H. arbuscula is endemic to the island of Maui, and H. oahuensis is endemic to Oahu island.

The taxonomy is questionable. Govaerts and Dransfield (2005) treat this as an unplaced name (see Govaerts, R. & Dransfield, J. 2005. World Checklist of Palms: 1-223. The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew).
Some authors consider Dionaea muscipula to be within the monotypic family Dionaeceae while others place it within Droseraceae (Weakley 2005).

Information from NatureServe (2003): "According to a personal communication cited in the Federal Register of Oct. 2, 1995, Warren Wagner concurs with St.John (who apparently described Phyllostegia kaalaensis in 1987) that P. kaalaensis is a valid, taxonomically distinct species. Kartesz (1999) recognizes it."
Treated by some as a variety under A. splendens (Achyranthes splendens var. atollensis (H. St. John) Govaerts) see World Checklist of Seed Plants 1(1): 6. 1995.

Synonym = Rollandia crispa.

Information from NatureServe (2003): "Tom Lammers et al. (1993) have merged all of the species of the endemic Hawaiian genus Rollandia under Cyanea. Kartesz 8/98 review draft dataset agrees, treating this as Cyanea crispa".

Synonym: Cyanea grimesiana ssp. cylindrocalyx.

Information from NatureServe (2003): "Treated as Cyanea grimesiana ssp. cylindrocalyx in the Hawaii Manual (Wagner et al., 1990); recognized as the species Cyanea cylindrocalyx in the Manual's Supplement (Wagner and Herbst, 1999) and by Kartesz (1999 Synthesis)".
The NatureServe NatureExplorer database (2003) lists this as Cyanea dunbarii.
Synoym = Cyanea macrostegia ssp. gibsonii.

Information from NatureServe (2003): "Phyllostegia mollis is a generally recognized endemic Hawaiian species, treated as multi-island by Wagner et al. (Manual, 1990) and USFWS (1991), but treated as an O`ahu endemic by Wagner and Herbst (Supplement, 1999). The Moloka'i and Maui plants formerly included in P. mollis were recognized by Wagner and Herbst (1999) as under the name P. haleakalae, and later by Wagner (Novon 9: 274-275, 1999) as P. pilosa, with the name P. haleakalae being considered instead an older name for the species generally known as P. imminuta".
Achyranthes atollensis, is placed by Govaerts as a variety under A. splendens, but it is kept separate here. See World Checklist of Seed Plants 1(1): 6. 1995.
Cenchrus setaceus (Forssk.) Morrone is a tertiary wild relative of pearl millet C. americanus (L.) Morrone (syn. Pennisetum glaucus) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017)

The true identity of this taxon remains unclear. This name is applied to multiple taxa within a complex of numerous cryptic species many of which are cultivated as ornametals, leading to the very wide distribution pattern (J. Leong-Škorničková pers. comm. 2020).
The correct generic name of this species is indeed Nasturtium microphyllum (Boenn.) Rchb.

The Yemen (and Arabian) plant is variety sinaica (Nees) Boeck, which is in fact intermediate between the mainly European C. distans and the central Asian C. diluta M. Bieb. In C. distans the gap between the male spike and the uppermost female spike is at least 1cm long and the beak of the fruit is very shallowly notched. In C. diluta the uppermost female spike is contiguous with the male spike and the beak of the fruit is deeply notched. Some Yemen plants (Wood 1246) approach C. distans, some approach C. diluta (Wood 2282) while others are hard to place (Wood 74/35) (Wood 1997).
Eleocharis uniglumis falls within a taxonomically difficult group including E. oxylepis, E. mamillata and E. palustris (Tutin et al. 1980) which would benefit from further investigation.

Lythrum hyssopifolium is one of a complex of small Lythrum species typically occurring in ephemeral wetlands and in association with larger, more permanent wetlands some of which are recognised by some authors as species (e.g. L. thymifolia). Taxonomic treatment of these entities is inconsistent.

A portion of the genus Polygonum was separated as Persicaria leaving only members of the Polygonum aviculare group in the original genus. Whilst generally widely accepted, IPNI and TROPICOS (for example) appear to retain Polygonum as the correct genus for this species, under which name it would be Polygonum amphibium L.

It has been shown that not only are some populations of Ranunculus subgenus Batrachium composed of complexes of polyploid clones attributable to a single taxon, but that other populations may be composed more or less entirely of hybrid combinations involving up to three parents and indistinguishable from each other or unhybridised plants without molecular analysis (Lansdown 2007). Several current and conflicting taxonomies (Castroviejo et al. 1986, Stace 1997, Jonsell 2000, Rothmaler 2005, van der Meijden 2005) co-exist and are applied in differing ways in Europe and it is clear from published information that both the identification guidance and recording are inconsistent between countries, regions and taxa.

Assessment of the taxa “most widely recognised” against the Red List Criteria is, at best, hopeful and an attempt has been made to explain any conclusions reached. Distribution data are mainly derived from the only truly critical account (Cook 1966) although it is clear that even that includes some inaccuracies. The exceptions to this are R. circinatus and R. hederaceus which may, at times, be misidentified but are taxonomically discrete.
Treated by Hunt et al. (2006) as a synonym of  Consolea spinosissima (Mill.) Lem., but it is now considered a valid species (Strittmatter et al. 2002, Areces-Mallea 1996).

Allium schoenoprasum L. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the Allium group, including Onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh Onion (A. fistulosum L.), Leek (A. porrum L.) and Garlic (A. sativum L.) (Friesen et al. 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Two subspecies are native to Europe: A. schoenoprasum subsp. alpinum (DC.) Čelak. and A. schoenoprasum L. subsp. schoenoprasum (Euro+Med PlantBase 2006); these are primary wild relatives of Chives.

Three subspecies are recognized in Iberia: A. schoenoprasum subsp. orosiae, A. schoenoprasum subsp. latiorifolium and A. schoenoprasum subsp. schoenoprasum.

Brassica elongata Ehrh. comprises five subspecies: B. elongata Ehrh. subsp. elongata, B. elongata subsp. imdrhasiana Quézel, B. elongata subsp. integrifolia (Boiss.) Breistr., B. elongata subsp. pinnatifida (Schmalh.) Greuter & Burdet, and B. elongata subsp. subscaposa (Maire & Weiller) Maire (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019).Brassica elongata is a gene pool secondary wild relative of broccoli (B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck), Brussels sprout [B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker], cabbage (B. oleracea var. capitata L.), cauliflower (B. oleracea var. botrytis L.), kale (B. oleracea var. viridis L.) and turnip (B. rapa L.). It is also a gene pool tertiary wild relative of swede (B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb.), oilseed rape (B. napus L. var. napus) and perennial wall rocket [Diplotaxis tenuifolia (L.) DC.] (Vincent et al. 2013).

Brassica fruticulosa Cirillo seven subspecies: B. fruticulosa subsp. cossoniana (Boiss. & Reut.) Maire, B. fruticulosa subsp. fruticulosa, B. fruticulosa subsp. glaberrima (Pomel) Batt., B. fruticulosa subsp. mauritanica (Coss.) Maire, B. fruticulosa subsp. numidica (Coss.) Maire, B. fruticulosa subsp. pomeliana Maire and B. fruticulosa subsp. radicata (Desf.) Batt. (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019).Brassica fruticulosa is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Ethiopian cabbage (B. carinata A.Braun), swede (B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb.), oilseed rape (B. napus L. var. napus), black mustard (B. nigra (L.) W. D. J. Koch), turnip (B. rapa L.) and radish (Raphanus sativus L.) (Vincent et al. 2013). It is also a wild relative of broccoli (B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck), Brussels sprout (B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker), cabbage (B. oleracea var. capitata L.), cauliflower (B. oleracea var. botrytis L.) and kale (B. oleracea var. viridis L.) (Vincent et al. 2013).

In its wild form, Brassica nigra (L.) W.D.J. Koch is a primary wild relative of black mustard, the cultivated form of the species (Vincent et al. 2013), which is not that used anymore (OECD 2016). It is a gene pool secondary wild relative of Ethiopian cabbage (B. carinata A.Braun), mustard (B. juncea (L.) Czern.), broccoli (B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck), Brussels sprout (B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker), cabbage (B. oleracea var. capitata L.), cauliflower (B. oleracea var. botrytis L.), kale (B. oleracea var. viridis L.) and perennial wall rocket (Diplotaxis tenuifolia (L.) DC.). It is also a gene pool tertiary relative of swede (B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb.), oilseed rape (B. napus L. var. napus), turnip (B. rapa L.), radish (Raphanus sativus L.) and white mustard (Sinapis alba L.) (Vincent et al. 2013).

Lathryus tingitanus L. is rarely cultivated as an ornamental (Yunus 1990) and as fodder (Shehadeh et al. in prep), but only wild populations are considered in this threat assessment. In its wild form, L. tingitanus is a primary wild relative of Tangier Pea, the cultivated form of the species. According to Sarker et al. (2001), L. tingitanus is a secondary genetic wild relative of the cultivated Grass Pea (L. sativus L.). It is in the section Lathyrus (Shehadeh et al. in prep) and following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 2 of Chickling Vetch (L. cicera L.), Sweet Pea (L. odoratus L.) (Vincent et al. 2013), and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea (L. latifolius L.) and Caley Pea (L. hirsutus L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep). It is also in Taxon Group 4 of Cyprus Vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Spanish Vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

Lathyrus sylvestris L. is cultivated as an ornamental and forage (Sarker et al. 2001) but only wild populations are considered in this threat assessment. In its wild form, L. sylvestris is a primary wild relative of Flat Pea, the cultivated form of the species. According to Sarker et al. (2001), it is a secondary genetic wild relative of Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea (L. latifolius L.). It is in the section Lathyrus (Shehadeh et al. in prep) and following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 2 of Chickling Vetch (L. cicera L.), Sweet Pea (L. odoratus L.) (Vincent et al. 2013), the cultivated Grass Pea (L. sativus L.) and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Caley Pea (L. hirsutus L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep). More remotely, it is in Taxon Group 4 of Cyprus Vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Spanish Vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

The species is widely cultivated as an ornamental (Sarker et al. 2001) but only wild populations are considered in this threat assessment. Wild populations are therefore in Gene Pool 1B of their cultivated counterparts. In addition, L. latifolius L. is in the section Lathyrus (Shehadeh et al. in prep) and following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 2 of Grass Pea, L. sativus L (Shehadeh et al. in prep). However, according to Sarker et al. (2001), L. latifolius is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated Grass Pea, and genetic crossing information should be used where it is available (Maxted et al. 2006). Additionally, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 2 of Chickling Vetch (L. cicera L.), Sweet Pea (L. odoratus L.) (Vincent et al. 2013), and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species including Caley Pea (L. hirsutus L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep). It is in Taxon Group 4 of Cyprus Vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Spanish Vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

Lathyrus cicera L. is cultivated as a pulse and fodder (Sarker et al. 2001), but only wild populations are considered in this assessment. In its wild form, L. cicera is a primary wild relative of Chickling Vetch, the cultivated form of the species (Vincent et al. 2013). It is a secondary genetic wild relative of L. sativus L., the cultivated Grass Pea (Yunus 1990, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017), although some sources state it is a tertiary wild relative (Vincent et al. 2013). It belongs to the section Lathyrus (Shehadeh et al. in prep) and following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 2 of Chickling Vetch (L. cicera L.), Sweet Pea (L. odoratus L.) (Vincent et al. 2013), and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea (L. latifolius L.) and Caley Pea (L. hirsutus L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep). It is in Taxon Group 4 of Cyprus Vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Spanish Vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

The genus Utricularia is taxonomically complex, partly due to the desire of botanists to establish methods of identifying non-flowering populations (particularly in the field), with the consequence that the literature is complicated by vast numbers of unreliable records. Many taxa rarely flower and some have apparently never been known to flower in some regions. The majority of the data presented here is derived from Taylor (1989) which is the most reliable source. Additional information has been used where it is felt that it is both useful and reliable.

Much confusion has occurred between U. bremii and U. ochroleuca and literature records are not clear.

The genus Utricularia is taxonomically complex, partly due to the desire of botanists to establish methods of identifying non-flowering populations (particularly in the field), with the consequence that the literature is complicated by vast numbers of unreliable records. Many taxa rarely flower and some have apparently never been known to flower in some regions. The majority of the data presented here is derived from Taylor (1989) which is the most reliable source. Additional information has been used where it is felt that it is both useful and reliable.

Taylor (1989) suggests that U. ochroleuca may be "not one, but several, morphologically slightly different vegetative apomicts, each one with a different chromosome complement".

Ten varieties are recognized by Pedley in the Flora of Australia Vol. 11B (Orchard and Wilson 2001). It consists of a large complex of variable intergrading and hybridizing forms, some included in these ten varieties, others regarded as separate species: A. ayersiana, A. brachystachya, A. craspedocarpa, A. minyura, A. paraneura and A. ramulosa. These are distinguished mainly by leaf and pod characteristics (Moore 2005).

Acacia koa is very similar to Acacia koaia Hillebr. A. koaia has previously been assessed on the Red List (Bruegmann and Caraway 2003). For the purposes of this assessment A. koa Gray is treated as a separate species.
This species seems very closely related to A. herbacea and particularly to the more glabrate variant of the species, var. floridana (Wilburn 1975).

Within the genus Astragalus, the species cobrensis occupies subsection Strigulosis. Variety maguirei is distinguished from the typical form of the species by more copious pubescence, which is stiff and spreading.
Numerous hybridizing populations involving Baptisia leucophaea Nutt. and B. sphaerocarpa Nutt. Were identified over the entire range of B. sphaerocarpa (Alston and Turner 1963).
Erythrina variegata is a tree usually between 6-12 but up to 20 m, with much branched crown and coral flowers.
Several subspecies and varieties of this species are recognized.
Possibly of hybrid origin (Akiyama 1988).

The genus Lupinus is considered one of the most taxonomically difficult groups in the Pacific northwest, this is generally due to factors and process such as hybridization, introgression and phenotypic plasticity.

Isely (1986) recognized Lupinus westianus and L. aridorum as two separate populations of one species, based on the fact that the only exomorphic character differentiating the two was the flower colour. Consequentially he identified the two entities as two different varieties, var. aridorum and var. westianus.
Rhynchosia minima is exceedingly difficult to divide into lower taxa, its range of variation is very great and experimental techniques are needed (Gillett et al. 1971).

The species has two varieties, var. guadalupensis which occurs in the United States (New Mexico and Texas) and var. gypsophila which occurs in northcentral Mexico. The varieties differ in that var. gypsophila has smaller seeds in narrowed pods (Poole et al. 2007).

There is some uncertainty about the taxonomic placement of this species, as it might be synonym of Tephrosia angustissima as suggested by Wunderlin and Hansen (2008), but is here treated as an accepted name until its taxonomic status is clarified.

Trifolium pratense L. belongs to section Trifolium and is a secondary wild relative of the cultivated crop crimson clover (T. incarnatum L.), as well as a primary wild relative of cultivated T. pratense (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

It has eight subspecies that are native to Europe: T. pratense ssp. baeticum (Boiss.) C. Vicioso, T. pratense ssp. expansum (Waldst. & Kit.) Hausskn., T. pratense ssp. kotulae (Pawl.) Soják, T. pratense ssp. maritimum (Zabel) Rothm., T. pratense ssp. nivale (W.D.J. Koch) Arcang., T. pratense L. ssp. pratense, T. pratense ssp. sativum (Schreb.) Schübl. & G.Martens, and T. pratense ssp. semipurpureum (Strobl) Pignatti. There are a further four varieties of T. pratense that are native to Europe: T. pratense var. americanum Harz, T. pratense var. frigidum Gaudin, var. T. pratense maritimum Zabel, and T. pratense var. pratense.

Trifolium subterraneum L. belongs to section Trichocephalum, and is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated species T. repens L. (white clover) and T. pratense L. (red clover) (Zohary and Heller 1984, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). It has three subspecies native to Europe: Trifolium subterraneum L. ssp. subterraneum, Trifolium subterraneum L. ssp. oxaloides Nyman and Trifolium subterraneum L. ssp. yanninicum Kayzn. & F. H. Morley (Euro+Med PlantBase 2010).

Zapoteca formosa consists of six highly variable subspecies: formosa, salvadorensis, gracilis, rosei, mollicula and schottii. This infraspecific classification is based primarily on leaf and flower characters (Hernandez 1989).

Ipomoea lacunosa L. is in the series Batatas (Khoury et al. 2015). It is a tertiary wild relative of Sweet Potato, I. batatas (L.) Lam. var. batatas (L.) Lam. (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).

Ipomoea tenuissima Choisy is in the series Batatas (Khoury et al. 2015). It is a tertiary genetic wild relative and probable progenitor of Sweet Potato, I. batatas (L.) Lam. var. batatas (L.) Lam. (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).

Ipomoea cordatotriloba Dennst. is in the series Batatas (Khoury et al. 2015) and comprises three varieties (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018): var. australis (O’Donell) D.F.Austin, var. cordatotriloba and var. torreyana (A.Gray) D.F.Austin. The latter should not be recognised for this taxon (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018).

Ipomoea cordatotriloba is a tertiary genetic wild relative of Sweet Potato, I. batatas (L.) Lam. var. batatas (L.) Lam. (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).

Helianthus anomalus belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group 4 of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

The species Helianthus deserticola is sometimes incorporated into broad taxonomic concepts of H. anomalus (e.g. Kartesz 1999, Utah Heritage Program), and despite indications that the two species are molecularly distinct, Cronquist (1994) states that they are not otherwise distinguishable (NatureServe 2013). 

However, the Flora of North America (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006) states that H. deserticola has an abundance of subsessile glands on stems, leaves, phyllaries and abaxial faces of ray laminae which distinguish the two species from one another.
Helianthus argophyllus Torr. & A.Gray belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus arizonensis R.C.Jacks. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus atrorubens L. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus bolanderi is closely related, and morphologically similar, to H. exilis (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006) which is also sometimes referred to as the Aerpentine Sunflower (i.e. California Native Plant Society (CNPS) 2013).

It is belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and to Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus californicus DC. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and to Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L. (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Helianthus debilis Nutt. has five subspecies with various distributions within Northern America: the Cucumber Leaf Sunflower (H. debilis subsp. cucumerifolius), the Forest Sunflower (H. debilis subsp. silvestris), the Beach Sunflower (H. debilis subsp. debilis), the Clothed Sunflower (H. debilis ssp. vestitus), and the Slow Flowering Sunflower (H. debilis subsp. tardiflorus).

H. debilis belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of the cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
The species Helianthus deserticola belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus divaricatus L. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

This species is morphologically similar to Helianthus bolanderi, and is often included in the latter's taxonomic concept despite discrete differences between the two species (see Rogers et al. 1982, Rieseberg et al. 1988, Jain et al. 1992, Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).

It belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L.
Helianthus giganteus L. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus grosseserratus M.Martens belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and to Taxon Group two of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus maximiliani Schrad. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus neglectus Heiser belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus niveus (Benth.) Brandegee belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L. (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Helianthus nuttallii has three subspecies, H. nuttallii subsp. nuttallii, H. nuttallii subsp. rydbergi and H. nuttallii subsp. parishii. The former two are native to both Canada and the United States of America and the latter is thought only to occur in California.

This species belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus paradoxus is of hybrid origin; the parents are H. annuus and H. petiolaris (Rieseberg et al. 1991).

This species belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus pauciflorus Nutt. has two subspecies: H. pauciflorus subsp. pauciflorus and H. pauciflorus subsp. subrhomboideus (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

It belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus petiolaris Nutt. has two subordinate taxa: H. petiolaris subsp. fallax and H. petiolaris subsp. petiolaris (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

This species belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus praecox has three subordinate taxa: H. praecox subsp. praecox, H. praecox subsp. runyonii and H. praecox subsp. hirtus (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).

The species belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

This species hybridizes with Helianthus tuberosus L. and has often been given the misapplied name H. tomentosus Michaux, especially in cultivation (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006).

Helianthus resinosus Small belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus.
Helianthus salicifolius A.Dietr. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus silphioides Nutt. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus tuberosus L. belongs to the Taxon Group 1b of the cultivated Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus. It also belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L.

Cucurbita foetidissima Kunth is a tertiary wild relative of cushaw (C. argyrosperma C. Huber ssp. argyrosperma), fig-leaf gourd (C. ficifolia Bouche), maxima pumpkin/squash (C. maxima Duchesne), moschata pumpkin/squash (C. moschata Duchesne) and pepo pumpkin/squash (C. pepo L.) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

Cucurbita okeechobeensis is a secondary genetic relative of Moschata Pumpkin/Squash (C. moschata) and Pepo Pumpkin/Squash (C. pepo), and a tertiary genetic relative of Cushaw (C. argyrosperma), Fig-leaf Gourd (C. ficifolia) and Maxima Pumpkin/Squash (C. maxima) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).

According to Andres (1987), Cucurbita pepo L. comprises three subspecies: C. pepo L. ssp. pepo, C. pepo L. ssp. fraterna (L.H. Bailey) Lira et al., and C. pepo ssp. texana (A. Gray) Filov.

According to USDA, ARS, GRIN (2017), C. pepo ssp. pepo is only found in cultivation. C. pepo ssp. fraterna is the probable progenitor (and primary wild relative) of C. pepo ssp. pepo (pepo pumpkin/squash), as well a secondary wild relative of cushaw, C. argyrosperma C. Huber ssp. argyrosperma and moschata pumpkin/squash, C. moschata Duchesne, and a tertiary wild relative of fig-leaf gourd, C. ficifolia Bouche and maxima pumpkin/squash, C. maxima Duchesne (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

According to The Plant List (2013), C. pepo ssp. texana is a synonym of C. pepo var. texana (Scheele) D.S. Decker. USDA, ARS, GRIN (2017) does not list C. pepo ssp. texana (A. Gray) Filov but does list C. pepo ssp. texana (Scheele) Filov, nom. inval. as a synonym of C. pepo ssp. ovifera (L.) D.S. Decker var. texana (Scheele) Filov. This latter taxon is a primary wild relative of pepo pumpkin/squash, as well as a secondary wild relative of cushaw and moschata pumpkin/squash, and a tertiary wild relative of fig-leaf gourd and maxima pumpkin/squash (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Manihot angustiloba (Torr.) Müll. Arg. is a gene pool secondary wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013).
Manihot davisiae Croizat is a gene pool secondary relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013).
Manihot walkerae Croizat is a gene pool secondary wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013).
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
Hordeum depressum (Scribn. & J.G.Sm.) Rydb. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Hordeum pusillum Nutt. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Hordeum brachyantherum Nevski is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer 1995).

Elymus elongatus (Host) Runemark is a tertiary genetic wild relative of Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018), and of Intermediate Wheatgrass, Thinopyrum intermedium (Host) Barkworth & D.R.Dewey subsp. intermedium (Vincent et al. 2013).

According to Vincent et al. (2013) and USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System (2018) it is listed as a synonym of Thinopyrum elongatum. However, for example, the Missouri Botanical Garden (2018) considers E. elongatus an accepted name and T. elongatum as the synonym.
Hordeum arizonicum Covas is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).

In some sources, Elymus hispidus is listed as a synonym of Thinopyrum intermedium subsp. intermedium (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018), but The Plant List (2013) accepts Elymus hispidus (Opiz) Melderis and considers Thinopyrum intermedium as a synonym. In its wild form, Elymus hispidus (Opiz) Melderis is a primary wild relative of intermediate Wheatgrass, Thinopyrum intermedium (Host) Barkworth & D.R.Dewey subsp. intermedium, the cultivated form of the species (Vincent et al. 2013). It is also a tertiary genetic wild relative of Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).
Hordeum jubatum L. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).

Elymus farctus (Viv.) Runemark ex Melderis is a tertiary genetic wild relative of wheat, Triticum aestivum L. (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018) and of Intermediate Wheatgrass, Thinopyrum intermedium (Host) Barkworth & D.R.Dewey subsp. intermedium (Vincent et al. 2013).

In some sources, it is listed as a synonym of Thinopyrum junceum (L.) Á.Löve (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). However The Plant List (2013) states that Elymus farctus (Viv.) Runemark ex Melderis is an accepted name and Thinopyrum junceum is its synonym.

In the past A. palustris was considered as a subspecies of A. laxiflora and therefore today the species are still being confused.

Three subspecies are now recognized: Anacamptis palustris ssp. palustris, Anacamptis palustris ssp. robusta (Stephensen) Bateman, Prifgeon & Chase, A. palustris var. mediterranea (Guss.)
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

Carex rostrata has been shown to hybridise with C. acutiformis, C. hirta, C. lasiocarpa, C. pseudocyperus (C. ×justi-schmidtii Junge), C. riparia and C. vesicaria (C. ×involuta (Bab.) Syme) (Jermy et al. 2007). However, although C. ×involuta is fairly widespread and may form large stands, it tends to occur with one or both parents and none of these is considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name in Europe but there are some taxonomic issues to do with American populations.
This species is currently placed in genus Sporobolus by WCVP (2021), as Sporobolus alopecuroides (Piller & Mitterp.) P.M.Peterson.
This species is currently placed in genus Sporobolus by WCVP (2021), as Sporobolus schoenoides (L.) P.M.Peterson.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

There are no taxonomic issues affecting this name. The Flora of China includes L. exaltata within L. europaeus but we do not follow this treatment here. Some authorities recognise subspecies mollis and menthifolius but they are not recognised in this evaluation.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

C. atherodes is treated as C. orthostachys C.A. Mey. in the Flora of China (Dai Lunkai et al. in press). C. orthostachys C.A. Mey. is listed by the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010) and Elven (2007) as synonym of C. atherodes.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
Does not include the subspecies insularis.

Great variability, especially in degree of indumentum and leaf shape, has led to recognition of many microspecies and infraspecific taxa that are not satisfactorily separated when the species is investigated over its geographic range. Apparent hybridization between Lythrum salicaria and L. virgatum and among the many races of L. salicaria in eastern Europe and Asia has further confused the taxonomy (Haining Qin and Shirley A. Graham in Flora of China).

The global taxonomy of Baldellia has been clarified by Kozlowski et al. (2008) who recognise three species: B. alpestris (Coss.) Lainz, B. ranunculoides (L.) Parl. and B. repens (Lam.) Ooststr. ex Lawalree. These three taxa are recognised by most authorities and floras, although many recognise B. repens as a subspecies of B. ranunculoides. Euro+Med Plantbase (2006-2010) recognises B. alpestris but treats B. repens as a subspecies of B. ranunculoides.

The World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010) and Flora Iberica (Castroviejo et al. 2010) recognise the three taxa as species and this is the taxonomy that has been adopted here.

Inconsistent recording of the three taxa obscures the true status of populations in many regions.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
Taxonomy was recently revised (Lansdown 2008) to include C. hamulata as C. brutia var. hamulata; subsequently Stace (2009) proposed its elevation to subspecies.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

Barbarea vulgaris R. Br. is a primary wild relative of cultivated B. vulgaris (winter cress) and a wild relative of land cress, B. verna (Mill.) Asch.

Three subspecies are native to Europe: B. vulgaris ssp. arcuata (Opiz) Hayek, B. vulgaris ssp. rivularis (Martrin-Donos) Rothm. and B. vulgaris R.Br. ssp. vulgaris (Euro+Med PlantBase 2006).
Rorippa austriaca (Crantz) Besser is a wild relative of watercress, Nasturtium officinale W.T. Aiton and N. microphyllum Boenn. ex Rchb.

Rorippa islandica (Oeder) Borbás is a wild relative of watercress, Nasturtium officinale W.T. Aiton and N. microphyllum Boenn. ex Rchb. Two subspecies are native to Europe: R. islandica ssp. dogadovae (Tzvelev) Jonsell and R. islandica (Oeder) Borbás ssp. islandica.

Rorippa sylvestris (L.) Besser is a wild relative of watercress, Nasturtium officinale W.T. Aiton and N. microphyllum Boenn. ex Rchb. Two subspecies are native to Europe: R. sylvestris ssp. kerneri (Menyh.) Soó and R. sylvestris (L.) Besser ssp. sylvestris.

C. lasiocarpa has been shown to hybridise with C. riparia (C. ×evoluta Hartm.), C. vesicaria and C. rostrata (Jermy et al. 2007). However, none of these hybrids is frequent and they are not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.

Carex limosa has been shown to hybridise with C. magellanica and C. rariflora (Jermy et al. 2007). However, neither of these hybrids is frequent and they are not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.

C. pseudocyperus has been shown to hybridise with C. rostrata (C. ×justischmidtii Junge) and C. vesicaria (Jermy et al. 2007). However, neither of these hybrids is frequent and they are not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.

C. vesicaria has been shown to hybridise with C. hirta (C. ×grossii Fiek), C. riparia (C. ×csomadensia Simonk.) and C. rostrata (C. ×involuta (Bab.) Syme) (Jermy et al. 2007). However, although C. ×involuta is fairly widespread and may form large stands, it tends to occur with one or both parents and none of these is considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

Agrostis stolonifera L. is a wild relative of the cultivated form, creeping bent grass.

Valdés and Scholz; with contributions from Raab-Straube and Parolly (2009) recognize seven subspecies which are native to Europe: A. stolonifera ssp. albida (Trin.) Tzvelev, A. stolonifera ssp. filfiolia (Link) H. Scholz, A. stolonifera ssp. gaditana (Boiss. & Reut.) Valdés & H. Scholz, A. stolonifera ssp. maritima (Lam.) Vasc., A. stolonifera ssp. scabriglumis (Boiss. & Reut.) Maire, A. stolonifera ssp. stolonifera and A. stolonifera ssp. straminea (Hartm.) Tzvelev. However, the subordinate taxa are poorly defined and taxonomic recognition between authors is inconsistent. It is therefore unlikely that taxonomic issues will affect the conservation or Red List assessment of this species.

G. fluitans has been shown to hybridise with G. notata (G. ×pedicellata F. Towns.) and G. declinata. However, neither of these hybrids is frequent and they are not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.

G. notata has been shown to hybridise with G. fluitans (G. ×pedicellata F. Towns.), however, although this hybrid is locally frequent and it is not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
Two taxa are sometimes recognised within J. bulbosus: J. bulbosus L. and J. kochii F.W. Schultz. The validity of J. kochii is still uncertain.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

A robust variety has been introduced to the UK with North American seed mixtures and the species certainly appears to be increasing as an alien (K. Walker in Preston et al. 2002). However given that it is not native to North America (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010) this form must have its origins elsewhere.
M. spicata is known to hybridise with a number of other Mentha species.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
L. portula has been separated from Lythrum as Peplis portula in the past, but is now generally included in Lythrum. There are no significant taxonomic issues affecting this name.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

A portion of the genus Polygonum was separated as Persicaria leaving only members of the Polygonum aviculare group in the original genus. Whilst generally widely accepted, IPNI and TROPICOS (for example) appear to retain Polygonum.

Hybrids have been reported between this taxon and other Persicaria species, but reliable evidence is sparse; as suggested by Flora Nordica hybridisation is likely to be rare and is unlikely to affect the red list assessment.

Wiegleb and Kaplan (1998) included P. berchtoldii as a synonym of P. pusillus L., however the taxa are accepted as separate species by the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families ( The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010). The two species were combined in the cited publication because at that time this was the only convenient concept for the extremely rich mosaic of phenotypes at the worldwide scale. However, the concept of P. berchtoldii and P. pusillus as separate species was confirmed by isozyme analysis by Kaplan and Štěpánek (2003).

P. berchtoldii is known to hybridise with P. acutifolius (P. ×sudermanicus), P. coloratus P. ×lanceolatus), P. natans (P. ×variifolius) and P. polygonifolius (P. ×rivularis) but these hybrids are rare and hybridisation is unlikely to affect the survival of the species.

P. gramineus is not only an extremely polymorphic species, showing considerable variation in size, scale and the morphology of vegetative parts in relation to environmental influences, but is also known to hybridise with a large number of other species, making taxonomic delineation very difficult (Wiegleb and Kaplan 1998).

In Europe, P. gramineus has been shown to hybridise with P. alpinus (P. ×nericius Hagstr.), P. coloratus (P. ×billupsii Fryer), P. lucens (P. ×angustifolius J. Presl in Bercht. et J. Presl,), P. natans (P. ×sparganiifolius Laest. ex Fr.), P. perfoliatus (P. ×nitens Weber) and P. polygonifolius (P. ×lanceolatifolius (Tiselius) C. D. Preston). Some of these hybrids are relatively frequent and where poorly elucidated may obscure the true distribution of P. gramineus, however they are unlikely to affect either the status of the species or this evaluation as they most often occur in the presence of P. gramineus.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. P. praelongus has been shown to hybridise with P. alpinus (P. ×griffithii A. Benn.), P. crispus (P. ×undulatus Wolfg. in Schult. et Schult. and P. perfoliatus (P. ×cognatus Asch. et Graebn.), all of these hybrids are rare and are unlikely to affect the survival of this species or this evaluation.
There are no known taxonomic issues affecting this name.

The normal concept of R. flammula includes some subordinate taxa (such as ssp. scotica) and some hybrids (e.g. R. ×levenensis Druce ex Gornall), however this is not considered likely to affect this evaluation or the status of the species.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. S. angustifolium has been shown to hybridise with S. emersum (S.×diversifolium Graebner), although this hybrid may be common, it is not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

Six subspecies are recognised by Cook and Nicholls (1987), of which four occur in Europe: ssp. erectum, ssp. microcarpum (Neuman) Domin, ssp. neglectum (Beeby) K. Richt. and ssp. oocarpum (Celak.) Domin.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

It is likely that S. natans hybridises with S. hyperboreum, hybrids are rare and are unlikely to affect either the survival of the species or this assessment.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
