Considerable confusion exists in the taxonomic literature over the status of Acorus in North America. Whether Acorus is native or introduced, as well as the number of taxa in North America, has been debated for years. Evidence based on studies of morphology, essential oil chemistry, cytology, isozymes, and ethnobotany supports the existence of two species in North America; A. calamus, an introduced sterile triploid, and A. americanus, a native fertile diploid. A. americanus is not only morphologically distinct from triploid A. calamus but also from diploid and tetraploid A. calamus populations occurring in Asia (Thompson 2002).

In this assessment, the distinction is not recognised.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

Cypripedium variegatum Georgi. is an invalid synonym

Cypripedium orientale Spreng. is an illegitimate synonym

Hydrastis is sometimes placed in its own family, Hydrastidaceae, with one other monotypic genus, Glaucidium, which is restricted to Japan (Tobe 2003). However, under the Angiosperm Phylogeny scheme, they are placed under Ranunculaceae (Stevens 2001).

The species has taxonomic issues and so far there are no conclusive studies. It is considered as a complex of species, being considered a species for some authors or instead a variety (Cyperus virens var. drumondii) by other experts (L. Pereira da Silva pers. comm. 2020).

Populations of Carex canescens (section glareosae) are a variable complex which comprise 39 subordinate taxa (29 varieties, one form and nine subspecies).

Until recently, C. canescens has been treated in most of the European literature as C. curta Gooden.

C. canescens has been shown to hybridize with C. appropinquata, C. chordorrhiza (C. ×liddii Flatb.), C. dioica (C. ×macrostachya Ehrh.), C. echinata (C. ×biharica Simonk.), C. elongata, C. lachenallii (C. ×helvola Blytt ex Fr.), C. paniculata (C. ×ludibunda J. Gay), C. remota and others (Jermy et al. 2007). However, none of these hybrids is frequent and they are not considered likely to affect the survival of the species.
The wild Helianthus annuus is considered a primary genetic relative of the cultivated Sunflower (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).

Rubus ellipticus Sm. is a primary genetic relative of the red raspberry, R. idaeus L. (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019). The synonymy of R. ellipticus Sm. requires clarification as there is a lack of consensus among published sources as to its synonymy (Evans et al. 2007). For example, Plants of the World Online lists just two synonyms, while the Medicinal Plant Names Services, using unpublished World Checklist data, includes 13 scientific synonyms. The synonyms listed are those cited by at least one of the following taxonomic sources: Plants of the World Online; Medicinal Plant Names Service or GRIN taxonomy (Board of Trustees, RBG Kew 2019a, Board of Trustees, RBG Kew 2019b, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019). Of these, the most commonly applied are R. ellipticus Sm. var. ellipticus and R. ellipticus Sm. var. obcordatus (Franche.) Focke (CABI 2019).
Only the most relevant synonyms are listed. For a complete list of synonyms please see WCSP (2018).This species often hybridizes with Psidium guineense and is often confused with it (Landrum 2017).

Amygdalus minutiflora (Engelm. ex A Gray) W.Wright is a synonym of Prunus minutiflora Engelm ex. A. Gray. This species is a secondary genetic relative of Peach (Prunus persica (L.) Batsch) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Amygdalus texana (D. Dietr.) W.Wright is a synonym of Prunus texana D.Dietr.

This species is a secondary genetic relative of Japanese Plum (Prunus salicina Lindl.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Prunus besseyi L.H.Bailey belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh., Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch and Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl.; it is also used as graft stock for apricot P. armeniaca L., Sweet Cherry P. avium (L.) L. and Plum P. domestica L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Prunus hortulana L.H. Bailey belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh. and Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl., it also belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Prunus maritima Marshall belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Plum P. domestica L. and is used as graftstock for Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Prunus munsoniana W.Wight & Hedrick has been used in plant breeding for the improvement of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh (Faust and Surányi 1998).

This species is considered a synonym of P. rivularis Scheele in the Flora of North America (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006), however The Plant List (2013) treats these two taxa as separate species, this is also the case in NatureServe (2013). Here the taxonomy used follows that of The Plant List.

Some taxonomists recognize Prunus murrayana as an accepted species (e.g. Kartez 1994), while some class it as a synonym of Prunus rivularis var. pubescens (e.g. Enquist 1997).

It belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh. and Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

This species belongs to the Rosaceae family, and is generally recognized as a synonym of Prunus andersonii A.Gray (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2015).

It is a tertiary genetic relative of Apricot P. armeniaca L., myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh. and Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2015).
Prunus pensylvanica L.f. has been used as graftstock for breeding Sour Cherry P. cerasus L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resource Program 2013).

Prunus rivularis Scheele belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh. and Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl.; it has also been used as graftstock for Apricot P. armeniaca and Plum P. domestica L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

This species is considered a synonym of P. munsoniana W.Wight & Hedrick in the Flora of North America (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006), however, The Plant List (2013) treats these two taxa as separate species, this is also the case in NatureServe (2013). Here the taxonomy used follows that of The Plant List.
Prunus subcordata Benth. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Plum P. domestica L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus umbellata Elliot belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Prunus americana Marshall belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of peach P. persica (L.) Batsch and Japanese plum P. salicin Lindl.; it is also a tertiary genetic relative of plum P. domestica L. and is used as graft stock for apricot P. armeniaca L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus angustifolia Marshall belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Japanese Plum P. salicina (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus emarginata (Douglas) Eaton belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sweet Cherry P. avium (L.) L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus gracilis Engelm. & Gray belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In the literature, the spelling of this species' taxonomy varies from Prunus harvardii to Prunus havardii.

It belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus mexicana S.Watson belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Until recently B. cordifolia has been regarded as a variety, or a northerly or montane form of B. papyrifera. Furlow (1997) in the Flora of North America questions whether it deserves specific status. However, the studies of Brittain & Grant (1965b, 1967b) and Grant & Thompson (1975) confirmed the diploid status of B. cordifolia, defined its morphological distinctness, and suggest that it is likely to be one of the constituent genomes of hexaploid B. papyrifera. Reports of tetraploids in B. cordifolia are likely to be due to the great difficulty in distinguishing between B. cordiolia and the B. cordifolia x B. papyrifera hybrid.

Murray’s birch is a rare species of birch (Betula murrayana) described by Barnes & Dancik (1985). Furlow (1997) recognizes Murray’s birch as Betula murrayana. Ashburner & McAllister (2013) in their taxonomic revision of the genus Betula treat Murray’s birch as a species, Betula murrayana: "this species is an unusual natural hybrid of an already naturally hybridized species, Betula x purpusii, crossed with another native species, B. allegheniensis".
Strumpfia maritima is the only species in the genus.
This species has two varieties: Cordia sebestena L. var. sebestena and Cordia sebestena L. var. caymanensis (Urb.) Proctor.
This species has two subspecies, Varronia bullata L. subsp. bullata and Varronia bullata L. subsp. humilis (Jacq.) Feuillet.
Echinochloa polystachya  (Kunth) Hitche is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of White millet/ Siberian millet (Echinochloa frumenlacca Link) (Vincent et al. 2013)

Juglans californica was previously split into two varieties, var. californica and var. hindsii. Now each variety is treated as separate species (Juglans californica and Juglans hindsii). As such these two species are assessed independently on the IUCN Red List.

Lathyrus rotundifolius Willd. is widely and commonly used in horticulture (Sarker et al. 2001), but only wild populations are considered in this threat assessment. In its wild form, L. rotundifolius is a primary wild relative of Round-leaf Vetchling, the cultivated form of the species. It is in the section Lathyrus (Shehadeh et al. in prep) and following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is classified in Taxon Group 2 of Chickling Vetch (L. cicera L.), Sweet Pea (L. odoratus L.) (Vincent et al. 2013), the cultivated Grass Pea (L. sativus L.), and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea (L. latifolius L.) and Caley Pea (L. hirsutus L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep). It is also classified in Taxon Group 4 of Cyprus Vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Spanish Vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

The two subspecies of Pyrus communis L., P. communis subsp. caucasica (Fed.) Browicz and P. communis subsp. pyraster (L.) Ehrh. (syn. P. pyraster (L.) Baumg.), are wild relatives of cultivated pear, P. communis subsp. communis.

Quince, Cydonia oblonga Mill., is cultivated globally as a crop for fruit production (Kafkas et al. 2018). Accordingly, wild quince is a wild relative of cultivated quince under Taxon Group 1b, according to the taxon group definition by Maxted et al. (2006).
Malus fusca (Raf.) C.K.Schneid. is a tertiary genetic relative of the cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.
The lectotypification of  Crataegus coccinea L. and its conspecificity with C. pedicellata Sarg. is discussed by Phipps et al. (2003).
There are three recognized subspecies of Populus deltoides: subsp. monilifera, subsp. deltoides, and subsp. wislizeni each has a distinct geographic range (Ekenwalder 2018).

There continues to be debate as to whether this taxon is named Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Hooker & Arnott) Manos, Cannon & S.Oh or Lithocarpus densiflorus (Hooker & Arnott) Rehder.

Immel (2002), WCSP (2018), and Jepson Flora Project (2018) recognize Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Hooker & Arnott) Manos, Cannon, & S.Oh as the accepted nomenclature.

Flora of North America (Nixon 1997), ITIS (2018) and Tropicos (2018); recognize Lithocarpus densiflorus (Hooker & Arnott) Rehder as the accepted nomenclature.

This assessment will use the species name Notholithocarpus densiflorus.

Citron, Citrus medica L., is a primary wild relative of cultivated Citron, and a close wild relative of all cultivated Citrus spp. (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2020). Citrus taxonomy is complex and has been subject to multiple revisions. Barrett and Rhodes (1976) pointed to just three true species in the genus: C. medica, C. maxima, and C. reticulata. However, a recent comprehensive study into the genomics and taxonomy of the genus has concluded that ten natural citrus species exist, including the three identified by Barrett and Rhodes (Wu et al. 2018).
This species is often confused with Fimbristylis miliacea in Indian floristic works. Fimbristylis miliacea is mostly common in north India (Cook 1996).

M. fontana has been taxonomically divided into a series of varieties, subspecies or even species. Recognition of these entities is very inconsistent and there appears to be no useful solution to sub-specific treatment of this taxon.

It has been shown that not only are some populations of Ranunculus subgenus Batrachium composed of complexes of polyploid clones attributable to a single taxon, but that other populations may be composed more or less entirely of hybrid combinations involving up to three parents and indistinguishable from each other or unhybridised plants without molecular analysis (Lansdown 2007). Several current and conflicting taxonomies (Castroviejo et al. 1986, Stace 1997, Jonsell 2000, Rothmaler 2005, van der Meijden 2005) co-exist and are applied in differing ways in Europe and it is clear from published information that both the identification guidance and recording are inconsistent between countries, regions and taxa.

Assessment of the taxa “most widely recognised” against the Red List Criteria is, at best, hopeful and an attempt has been made to explain any conclusions reached. Distribution data are mainly derived from the only truly critical account (Cook 1966) although it is clear that even that includes some inaccuracies. The exceptions to this are R. circinatus and R. hederaceus which may, at times, be misidentified but are taxonomically discrete.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
Galeandra bicarinata was split from Galeandra beyrichii as a distinct species (Romero and Brown 2000).

Previously, debate existed about the whether Malaxis bayardii was distinct from Malaxis unifolia, at which time the former was often treated as a synonym for the latter (Catling 1991). However, Catling (1991) determined that M. bayardii is morphologically distinct from M. unifolia. Additionally, Catling (1991) found that the two species possess distinct patterns of distribution and habitat preference; M. bayardii is found in very dry sites and M. unifolia is found in sites “characterized by periodic water accumulation.” Thus, M. bayardii is confirmed as a separate species.

Wendt’s Adder’s-mouth Orchid was previously documented as Malaxis ehrenbergii in the United States (Todsen 1995), but was later reclassified as Malaxis wendtii Salazar (Salazar 1993). The genus name was revised in 1998; it is now also known as Tamayorkis wendtii (Tamayo and Szlachetko 1998).

Oncidium ensatum includes Oncidium floridanum. Authors of floristic literature (FNA 2002) lump O. floridanum with O. ensatum because studies of O. ensatum "reveal no characters consistent enough to warrant recognizing the Florida populations as a separate taxon (FNA 2002)."

Folsom (1984) indicates that Chapman’s Fringed Orchid (Platanthera chapmanii ) was described as a hybrid between the Orange Crested Orchid (Plantanthera cristata) and the Orange Fringed Orchid (Plantantherea ciliaris) erroneously. Folsom (1984) concludes that Chapman’s Fringed Orchid is not a hybrid, meaning Plantanthera x chapmanii, but a distinct taxon for several reasons including, it is “morphologically pure”, grows from seed, exists in areas independent of the other two taxon, etc. Chapman’s Fringed Orchid does hybridize with both of these species readily where they coexist; hybrids from these three closely related species are: Platanthera x apalachicola, Platanthera x channellii, Platanthera x osceola (Brown 2003, Brown and Stewart 2003). This hybridization does cause some confusion when distinguishing the species in areas where hybrids occur (Brown 2003).
The species was described in 2007 (Colwell et al. 2007). There are no taxonomic changes or doubts/debates regarding the validity or identity of this taxon.

Spiranthes torta excludes Spiranthes amesiana Schlechter which is often considered conspecific with S. torta. Recent studies support that it is distinct based on several differences: S. torta has a denser inflorescence, spade-shaped lip with a crenulate-ciliate margin, and densely pubescent basal calli than S. amesiana (FNA 2002).
Spiranthes brevilabris var. floridana was elevated to the species rank, therefore Spiranthes brevilabris reviewed here excludes S. floridana.

Navasota Ladies-tresses (Spiranthes parksii) cannot be genetically distinguished from the open-flower form of Spiranthes cernua (Walters 2005). The Navasota Ladies-tresses Orchid can be morphologically distinguished from Spiranthes cernua “by its upcurved and long lateral sepals relative to the petals as well as its white-tipped floral bracts” (Walters 2005).

Triphora latifolia was thought to be endemic to Florida endemic but the understanding of the taxon expanded when Ackerman (1995) determined vegetative material from Puerto Rico as T. latifolia. In 1995, the distribution of T. latifolia was thought to be Florida, Puerto Rico and Brazil, which is a bit unusual. A careful comparison between T. latifolia and T. amazonica revealed that the only detectable difference between the taxa was the middle lobe of the lip, which may be rounded in T. latifolia or acute in T. amazonica (Ackerman 2000). Triphora amazonica ranges from Brazil to Guyana, French Guiana, Surinam, Trinidad and Dominican Republic, which makes a link with Puerto Rico and Florida. Morphological and geographical information provide evidence that these two taxa are conspecific. Additional specimens are needed to confirm the full geographic extent of T. amazonica sensu lato and that T. amazonica sensu lato is one distinct species throughout its range. The taxonomic treatment followed here indicates that some rare species have much greater range extents than previously thought (Ackerman 2000).

FNA (2002) and Fernández-Concha (2012) lump Triphora yucatanensis and T. rickettii (T. rickettii segregated Florida material). Some differences are noted between the disjunct subpopulations including the shape of the labellum (resupinate in Florida plants) and flower colour (light violet spots in the apex of the labellum on Yucatan plants) (Fernández-Concha 2002, Luer 1996).

Helianthus hirsutus Raf. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated H. annuus L. and to Taxon Group two of H. tuberosus L. (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Helianthus decapelatus belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group two of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L. (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).

Chisos Mountain Crested Coralroot (Hexalectris revoluta Correll) and Coleman’s Coralroot (Hexalectris colemanii) were previously considered the same taxon (Coleman 2000). However, they are now regarded as distinct (Catling 2004, Kennedy and Watson 2010). Coleman’s Coralroot is found in the United States in the state of Arizona and is not included in this assessment.

This is a very variable species, particularly in West Africa where Hooper and Napper (1972) recognised three varieties. These were the typical variety, var. dichotoma, var. pluristriata (C.B. Clarke) Napper and var. laxa (Vahl) Napper. These subspecies and varieties have been recognised by different authors. Var. pluristriata was given subspecific rank by T. Koyama as Fimbristylis dichotoma subsp. podocarpa (Nees) T. Koyama, while var. laxa is at present on WCSP sunk into the typical species Fimbristylis dichotoma subsp. dichotoma. In some regions of Africa, namely South Africa and the area covered by the Flora Zambesiaca, Fimbristylis dichotoma is not as variable and the nutlets are entirely tuberculate like those of the typical variety as seen in West African countries.

J. effusus hybridises with J. inflexus L. (Juncus ×diffusus Hoppe) but the hybrid is not abundant and is unlikely to influence interpretation of the distribution of the species. Two varieties are widely recognised but there is little information on differences in their distribution or ecology, for example the apparent differences shown by Tela Botanica show that recording to varietal level is inconsistent, while Preston et al. (2002) do not map the different subspecies even though they are widely recorded in the UK.

Brooks and Clemants (2000) in Flora of North America vol. 22 say "The Juncus effusus complex has been variously recognized as containing several species or a single species with numerous infraspecific taxa. Unfortunately, North American treatments have dealt primarily with taxa in either the eastern or western portions of the continent. In considering the continent as a whole, little sense can be made of these treatments. The North American J. effusus complex is one that is in obvious need of modern systematic scrutiny."

The genus Utricularia is taxonomically complex, partly due to the desire of botanists to establish methods of identifying non-flowering populations (particularly in the field), with the consequence that the literature is complicated by vast numbers of unreliable records. Many taxa rarely flower and some have apparently never been known to flower in some regions. The majority of the data presented here is derived from Taylor (1989) which is the most reliable source. Additional information has been used where it is felt that it is both useful and reliable.
This species hybridizes and with Carya aquatica, C. glabra and C. tomentosa. It also integrades with C. pallida.
Information on the distribution of this and other strictly terrestrial Callitriche species is obscured by poor taxonomic resolution of the various taxa.
Various sources suggest that C. exsiccata grades into Carex vesicaria (possibly as C. vesicaria var major) and there is a need for taxonomic clarification.
There is a degree of taxonomic uncertainty over this species and others such as Eriophorum russeoleum to the extent that it its true distribution is not clear.

This taxon has been thought to be a hybrid between Hippuris tetraphylla and H. vulgaris. However, in northern Norway, western Alaska, Greenland, and the Canadian Arctic Archipelago it has been found to occur quite independent of its proposed parents (R. Elven in Aiken et al. 2003; R. Elven pers. comm. 2009; in NatureServe 2014).

The species is comprised of at least seven named varieties which are strongly correlated with well documented geographical, morphological and other differences such as allozyme and cytogenetic characteristics (Vickery 1990 in Penskar and Higman 2001)
S. bebbiana Sarg. is considered a synonym of Salix starkeana subsp. cinerascens (Wahlenb.) Hultén by Euro+Med (2015) (citing Uotila 2011), however retained based on I. Belyaeva (pers comm. 2015).

It is a secondary genetic relative and potentially the progenitor of Sweet Potato, I. batatas (L.) Lam. var. batatas (L.) Lam. (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).

This species' eastern Pacific distribution is now known as R. samoensis.

C. aquatilis has been shown to hybridise with C. acuta, C. bigelowii (C. ×limula Fr.), C. nigra (C. ×hibernica A. Benn.) and C. recta (C. ×grantii A. Benn.) (Jermy et al. 2007). However, none of these hybrids is frequent and they are not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.

A number of infraspecific taxa are recognised particularly in North America, some may merit species status (Elven 2007).

Lansdown (2008) split into two subspecies, subsp. hermaphroditica and subsp. macrocarpa. A further subspecies, Callitriche hermaphroditica subsp. exalata Tzvelev (Callitriche exalata (Tzvelev) Tzvelev) is accepted by WCVP (2021), however, the taxonomy of C. hermaphroditica north of the Caucuses is inadequately resolved at present, and this latter subspecies requires confirmation.

C. palustris is very variable throughout its range. In Europe, this variation is mainly represented by differences in the width and distribution of the wing and there are a few consistent variants in Europe which may merit description and for which more information is needed. Material from Corsica and the Pyrenees has ellipsoid fruits 0.9–1.1 x 0.6 mm, wingless or narrowly winged at the base and apex (Schotsman 1967). In some material from Russia the base of the mericarp twists outward, resembling C. peploides Nutt. In Asia there are additional differences in reproductive characters, so that five races can be recognised (Lansdown 2006). While occasional plants from eastern Europe are winged from base to apex and the wing is broader than in other populations (Schotsman 1967); these may represent the western extreme of populations of C. palustris var. elegans (Petrov) Y.L. Chang.

C. chordorrhiza has been shown to hybridise with C. canescens (C. ×liddii Flatb.) (Jermy et al. 2007), however, is not frequent and is not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.
Panicum stramineum Hitchc. & Chase is a secondary wild relative and potential breeding donor of broom millet, Panicum miliaceum L. ssp. miliaceum (Vincent et al. 2013).

Sorghum arundinaceum (Desv.) Stapf is a primary wild relative of sorghum, S. bicolor (L.) Moench, and Sudan grass, S. x drummondii (Nees ex Steud.) Millsp. & Chase (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019).

Kartesz (1994) recognized Quercus pungens var. vaseyana but Kartesz (1999) and Flora North America (1997) now treat Q. pungens and Q. vaseyana as entirely distinct. FNA noted that the two species form hybrid swarms but there is no other evidence for a close relationship between the two.

The taxonomy of this species is not clear, it is treated as an accepted species within the P. sibiricus complex in the pan-Arctic Flora (Elven 2007) and by Wiegleb and Kaplan (1998) who note that "P. sibiricus is insufficiently known. Most probably it is related to P. oxyphyllus or P. compressus".
Status of the species in Scandinavia has been questioned and it is treated there as a variety.

Some authors consider American populations of this species to be different, which if accepted would mean that E. aquaticum is endemic to the United Kingdom and Ireland. Some retain E. aquaticum (Hill) Druce as the valid name if one accepts both North American and European plants as the same species (the alternative taken here). If North American plants are considered to be distinct from Eurasian ones, then the appropriate binomial for ours becomes E. pellucidum Michaux" (Kral 2000).
H. tetraphylla has been much confused with H. lanceolata (or H. x lanceolata) (Elven 2007) or even subsumed within H. vulgaris, by some authors.

Six subspecies of Poa pratensis L. are native to Europe: P. pratensis ssp. colpodea (Th. Fr.) Tzvelev, P. pratensis ssp. dolichophylla (Hack.) Portal, P. pratensis ssp. irrigata (Lindm.) H. Lindb., P. pratensis ssp. jordanii Portal, P. pratensis L. ssp. pratensis, and P. pratensis ssp. turfosa (Litv.) Vorosch. (Valdés and Scholz; with contributions from Raab-Straube and Parolly 2009).
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. Two varieties of P. epihydrus are recognised in North America but the distinctions are not clear with some British material.

Assumed eastward distribution of P. polygonifolius in Asia can be attributed to confusion with P. distinctus. Assumed southern Hemisphere distribution is due to confusion with southern species like P. suboblongus, P. cheesemanii, P. parmatus, and P. stenostachys. The occurrence in these areas has not yet been proved (Wiegleb and Kaplan 1998). P. polygonifolius is closely related to P. coloratus and P. suboblongus.

P. polygonifolius has been shown to hybridise with P. alpinus (P. ×spathulatus Schrad. ex W. D. J. Koch), P. berchtoldii (P. ×rivularis Gillot), P. gramineus (P. ×lanceolatifolius (Tiselius) C. D. Preston), and P. natans (P. ×gessnacensis G. Fisch.).
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name in Europe, but the taxonomic distinction between R. reptans and R. flammula in North America is less clear (Elven 2007).

R. reptans has been shown to hybridise with R. flammula ( R. × levenensis Druce ex Gornall) where their ranges overlap, however, this hybrid is infrequent and not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. It is likely that S. hyperboreum hybridises with S. natans, hybrids are rare and are unlikely to affect either the survival of the species or this assessment.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. P. vaginatus has been shown to hybridise with P. filiformis (P. ×fennicus Hagstr.) and P. pectinatus (P. ×bottnicus Hagstr.), although reasonably abundant, it is unlikely that these hybrids will affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

The name Q. turbinella was previously applied to scrub white oak subpopulations found from Arizona into Texas and northern mainland Mexico (now the typical Q. turbinella), as well as to scrub white oaks in southern California and Baja California. The latter of these have since been reassigned to Q. john-tuckeri and Q. cornelius-mulleri (Nixon 2002).

Recent reﬁnements in identiﬁcation based on a suite of features including acorn size, shape, colour and stalk length, leaf margin spine tooth regularity, and trichome characteristics, in addition to leaf form, resulted in the splitting of Quercus dumosa (sensu lato) into Q. dumosa sensu stricto, Q. berberidifolia, Q. cornelius-mulleri, Q. paciﬁca, and Q. durata (Nixon and Steele 1981, Nixon and Müller 1994, Nixon 2002).

Phaseolus acutifolius A. Gray is a tertiary wild relative of common bean, P. vulgaris L. var. vulgaris, scarlet runner bean, P. coccineus L. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). According to the same source, the species comprises two subtaxa: P. acutifolius var. acutifolius (which is both cultivated and occurs in the wild) and P. acutifolius var. tenuifolius A. Gray (which only occurs in the wild). P. acutifolius var. acutifolius is the progenitor of, and cultivated as tepary bean (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017), as well as being a tertiary wild relative of common and scarlet runner bean. Along with wild populations of P. acutifolius var. acutifolius, P. acutifolius var. tenuifolius is a primary wild relative of tepary bean, as well as being a tertiary wild relative of common and scarlet runner bean. A third taxon, P. acutifolius var. latifolius Freeman is recognized as a valid taxon by Freytag and Debouck (2002).
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate (typical) subspecies and subsp. exigua. Both subspecies are assessed separately.
On the Flora of the Hawaiian Islands website, Lysimachia ovoidea H.St.John is treated as a synonym of  Lysimachia hillebrandii Hook.f. ex A.Gray.

Lupinus polyphyllus Lindl. comprises various sub-taxa, but these depend on the taxonomic classfication. Barneby (1989) and Isely (1998) consider six botanical varieties, occupying distinct but somewhat overlapping distributions (var. ammophilus (Greene) Barneby, var. burkei (S. Watson) C. L. Hitchc., var. humicola (A. Nelson) Barneby, var. polyphyllus, var. prunophilus (M. E. Jones) L. Ll. Phillips and var. saxosus (Howell) Barneby) but some authors still maintain these as distinct species (Riggins and Sholars, 1993). USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System (2020), for example, considers var. ammophilus to be a synonym of L. ammophilus Greene var. ammophilus and The Plant List (2013) considers var. saxosus a synonym of L. saxosus Howell. Additionally, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System (2020) considers only five varieties: var. burkei, var. humicola, var. pallidipes, var. polyphyllus and var. prunophyllus.
Lupinus polyphyllus is cultivated as an ornamental (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2020) and as a forage (Wolkot et al. 2011), but sometimes it  escapes from cultivated fields and reach the biological category of exotic wild species, naturalize species or invasive weed (Planchuelo et al. 2003) in countries where it was introduced.This species is polymorphous and of easy hybridization with other related species (A. Planchuelo pers. comm. 2020). Only wild populations will be considered in this threat assessment. In its wild form, L. polyphyllus is a primary wild relative of large-leaf lupin, the cultivated form of the species. It is also one of the parents in crosses that formed the renowned Russell Hybrids, Lupinus × regalis, a popular garden ornamental in the UK (Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2019).
Nototrichium divaricatum Lorence is distinguished from its congeners by its compoundly branched iinflorescences with divaricate branches and shorter spikes.

Cryptocarya oahuensis (Degener) Fosberg occurring on Oahu has recently been separated from Cryptocarya mannii Hillebr. ocurring on Kauai based on DNA studies (Morden et al. 2015). This assessment is based on this narrow concept of Cryptocarya mannii as a single island endemic to Kauai. excluding C. mannii var. oahuensis Degener.
It has been postulated that the species represents a hybrid between Myrsine kauaiensis and M. wawraea, although the distribution of the latter does not coincide closely with that of M. mezii.
The name of this species is likely to soon be updated to Ceodes wagneriana based on molecular work showing Pisonia is not monophyletic (Rossetto and Caraballo 2020).
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
The species is known to hybridise with L. sessiliflora (Cook 1966).

Carex acutiformis has been shown to hybridise with C. riparia (C. ×sooi  Jákucs), C. vesicaria (C. ×ducellieri Beauverd) and C. acuta (C. ×subgracilis Druce) (Jermy et al. 2007). It also hybridises with C. rostrata. However, none of these hybrids is frequent and they are not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.

Although there is some uncertainty regarding the taxonomy of populations close to A. plantago-aquatica in Asia, these do not affect evaluation of the species in Europe.

Plants with the leaves similar to that of A. plantago-aquatica, styles as in A. gramineum and 0.2-0.3 mm long undeveloped anthers are known from Orenburg Region (basin of the Ural and Samara Rivers). Apparently this is the result of hybridization of A. plantago-aquatica × A. gramineum and possibly sterile. These are known as A. ×bjorkqvistii Tzvel. (Tzvelev 2001). This hybridisation is not sufficiently frequent to affect evaluation of the species.

A. plantago-aquatica is reported to hybridise occasionally with A. lanceolatum (A. ×rhicnocarpum Schotsm.) but this is not sufficiently frequent to affect evaluation of the species in Europe.

Throughout much of its range, Juncus bufonius represents a complex of taxa. TROPICOS lists 80 sub-specific combinations for this name, but Flora Europaea volume 5 lists the following as falling within the J. bufonius group: J. bufonius L., J. foliosus Desf., J. hybridus Brot., J. minutulus (Albert & Jahand.) Prain, J. ranarius Nees and J. sorrentini Parl. Some of these are recognized in some countries or by some authors but use is not consistent, thus, for example in the UK J. minutulus is considered a synonym of J. bufonius, while J. ranarius is treated as s synonym of J. ambiguus Guss., equally TROPICOS treats J. hybridus as a nomenclatural synonym of J. bufonius L. but IPNI does not. Work is needed to achieve a degree of consistency in recording of taxa within the J. bufonius group. Kirschner (2002) treats Juncus hybridus (= ambiguus), and J. ranarius as distinct species and does not include them in J. bufonius.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. However, there is a degree of confusion over separation of L. gibba from L. minor when the former is not expanded and this may obscure differences in the distribution of the two species.

Lobelia gaudichaudii subsp. gaudichaudii was formerly classified as a subspecies until 2007 (Lammers 2007).  Lobelia gaudichaudii subsp koolauensis was also classified as a subspecies of L. gaudichaudii until 2007 when both were elevated to species level with L. gaudichaudii having purple flowers and L. koolauensis having white flowers (Lammers 2007).
Was previously assessed under the genus Pleomele, but is now treated under Chrysodracon following (Lu and Morden 2014).

The taxonomy of the genus Zannichellia is complex, with one species recognised throughout much of the World but with many taxa recognised at or below species level in different regions. The distinguishing characters for some taxa appear to be useful, but others appear to have been described based on very few samples and relatively minor morphological differences. Most taxa described to-date are treated as Z. palustris by Kew (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010).

Multivariate analysis of morphometric data based on the Czech material did not support existence of any morphologically distinguishable taxa (Kaplan 2010).
The name is currently applied to a complex of one widespread species and a few stenoendemic species (J. Leong-Škornicková pers. comm.).

Ipomoea triloba L. is a tertiary genetic relative of Sweet Potato (I. batatas (L.) Lam.) (Jarret and Austin 1994, Huang et al. 2002, Rajapakse et al. 2004). Crossings involving I. triloba with the crop have resulted in relatively viable progeny (Nimmakayala et al. 2011).

Stictocardia tiliifolia has been confused with Ipomoea campanulata L. ( = S. campanulata (L.) Merr.), which is similar in general appearance and grows also along seacoasts. The glandular-dotted leaves, calyx, and corolla, and the non-capsular fruits enclosed in enlarged, leathery sepals are distinctive for S. tiliifolia. The nomenclature for S. tiliifolia has been the subject of some disagreement, and of the two different interpretations proposed, Austin et al. (Brittonia 30: 195-198. 1978) and Gunn (Brittonia 24: 169-176. 1972), the former is followed here.
Digitaria horizontalis Willd. is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Digitaria insularis (L.) Mez ex Ekman is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).

Solanum viarum Dunal is a tertiary wild relative of aubergine/egg plant, S. melongena L. (Vincent et al. 2013).

Physalis cinerascens (Dunal) Hitchc. is a wild relative of Cape gooseberry, P. peruviana L., low ground-cherry, P. pubescens L. and tomatillo, P. philadelphica Lam. The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

(2006), Phaseolus parvulus Greene is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of common bean, P. vulgaris L. var. vulgaris, Lima bean, P. lunatus L., scarlet runner bean, P. coccineus L., tepary bean, P. acutifolius A. Gray var. acutifolius and year bean, P. dumosus Macfad.

Huber ssp. argyrosperma), fig-leaf gourd (C. ficifolia Bouche), maxima pumpkin/squash (C. maxima Duchesne), moschata pumpkin/squash (C. moschata Duchesne) and pepo pumpkin/squash (C. pepo L.) Although there is great variation in habit and stature in the trees associated with different habitats there are no clear boundaries between the different forms. The most useful taxonomic treatment is to give names to the most distinct, but only at the varietal level. Therefore var. pubescens for the tall central European and southern British and Scandinavian populations, var. pumila for northern populations, which are probably derived from var. pubescens through adaptive selection and introgression from B. nana, var. fragrans for aromatic, small leaved trees from northwest Britain, and var. litwinowii for Anatolian and Caucasian populations which are probably largely the result of introgression from B. pendula.

Betula coriacea and B. concinna from Sweden remain enigmatic, similar to one another, and distinct from other forms of B. pubescens.

Betula turtuosa, B. borysthenica, B. kusmischeffii, B. rezniczenkoana, B. kelleriana, B. ircutensis and B. baicalensis await further study.

Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats; including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum subsp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. subsp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum subsp. spelta (L.) Yucca aloifolia is the putative maternal parent and Y. filamentosa is the putative paternal parent of the homoploid hybrid species Y. gloriosa (Rentsch & Leebens-Mack 2012).

We are here assessing Yucca angustissima to include Y. angustissima var. angustissima and Y. angustissima var. avia. Based on DNA analyses (Clary 1997), morphology and distribution, two of the four recognised varieties, Yucca angustissima var. toftiae and Y. angustissima var. kanabensis, are treated and assessed as separate species. Further DNA analyses are needed on Y. angustissima var. avia, which may also deserve species recognition.

Yucca arizonica is here considered a synonym of Yucca baccata. Flora of North America recognises two varieties, Yucca arizonica var. baccata and Y. arizonica var. brevifolia Benson & Darrow. Yucca arizonica McKelvey and Y. thornberi McKelvey are considered synonyms of Y. arizonica var. brevifolia. Yucca arizonica may be a distinct taxon, the complex requiring further systematic work with excellent documentation with specimens and photos. Yucca baccata hybridises with Yucca baileyi, Yucca angustissima, Yucca utahensis, and Yucca elata (W. Hodgson pers. comm 2018, SEINet).

Some subpopulations of Yucca baileyi comprise compact colonies of semi-erect, branched plants instead of scattered, cespitose individuals (Hess and Robbins 2002). Webber (1993) recognized these subpopulations as Y. baileyi var. navajoa, who noted that Y. baileyi possibly hybridizes with Y. glauca and Y. angustissima. Yucca baileyi var. navajoa and Y. baileyi var. baileyi do hybridize with Y. baccata (W. Hodgson, pers. comm. 2018; SEINet 2018). Additional systematic research is needed to determine the appropriate status of Y. baileyi var. navajoa.

For some time, botanists only recognised one species of Joshua tree, Yucca brevifolia. However, Lenz (2007) clarified significant differences between eastern (Y. jaegeriana) and western (Y. brevifolia) subpopulations. Yucca brevifolia is arborescent with a distinct trunk and stout branches, while Y. jaegeriana is generally smaller with somewhat smaller branches arising from the base. Yucca brevifolia also has monopodial branching while those of Y. jaegeriana has a dichotomous branching pattern (Rowlands 1978). Yucca brevifolia also has longer leaves (15-35 cm vs. 10-20 cm).  The flowers of the two species are very distinctive, with those of Y. brevifolia being globular in shape, with tepals fleshy, broadly ovate, strongly incurved, cream-coloured, and never expanding fully and ovaries conical. Those of Y. jaegeriana are narrowly campanulate, swollen at base, with tepals narrowly oblong and greenish, and recurved and ovaries lance-ovoid.  Fruits of Y. brevifolia are ovoid to broadly ovoid while those of Y. jaegeriana are ellipsoid.  In addition, Y. brevifolia is pollinated by Tegeticula synthetica (Riley, 1892), while Y. jaegeriana is pollinated by a different species, T. anthithetica (Pellmyr, 2003). The only confirmed region of sympatry between Y. brevifolia and Y. jaegeriana is a small area in Tikaboo Valley (Lincoln County), Nevada (Rowlands 1978, Smith et al. 2009).
Yucca filamentosa is the putative paternal parent and Y. aloifolia is the putative maternal parent of the homoploid hybrid species Y. gloriosa (Rentsch & Leebens-Mack 2012).

Rentsch and Leebens-Mack (2012) present data from both chloroplast haplotype and nuclear gene-based microsatellite data support the homoploid Yucca gloriosa. Their data indicate that Yucca gloriosa is the product of intersectional hybridization between Y. aloifolia L. and Y. filamentosa L. While the nuclear data point towards only a single hybrid origin of Y. gloriosa, lack of variation in the chloroplast of the putative maternal parent, Y. aloifolia, makes it difficult to rule out multiple hybrid origins.

The original description of Yucca necopina was based only on plants from a single locality in Somervell County.  Shinners’ (1958) sketchy description compared it with Y. arkansana, and he suggested that it might be a hybrid between Y. pallida and Y. arkansana. More recently, G. M. Diggs et al. (1999) noted that molecular evidence provided to them by K. H. Clary supports its separate recognition (Hess and Robbins 2002).

Yucca neomexicana is considered by Kartesz (1994) to be a variety of Yucca harrimaniae, but Hess and Robbins (2002) recognised it as a species. Reveal (1977) reduced Yucca neomexicana to a variety of Y. harrimaniae, but the two taxa are morphologically and geographically distinct; also, Clary and Simpson´s (1995) DNA evidence supports their recognition as separate species (Hess and Robbins 2002).

According to Hess and Robbins (2002), Yucca pallida was originally included in Y. rupicola.  J. M. Webber (1953) indicated that he found plants of Y. rupicola with key features similar to those of Y. pallida. Occasionally, plants with entire margins are found; these have been called Y. pallida var. edentata, which S. D. McKelvey (1938, 1947) suggested might be a hybrid between Y. pallida and Y. arkansana. K. H. Clary (1997) indicated that DNA evidence confirms the close relationship of Y. pallida and Y. rupicola. Yucca pallida, Y. rupicola and Y. reverchoni are known to interbreed where their ranges overlap.

Yucca reverchonii is endemic to the Edwards Plateau. S. D. McKelvey (1947) indicated that Y. reverchonii occupies an area of the Plateau between those of Y. rupicola and Y. thompsoniana. J. M. Webber (1953) reported apparent hybrids of this species with Y. rupicola and Y. thompsoniana. K. Clary (1997) presented DNA evidence that confirms a close relationship among these three species as distinct entities (Hess and Robbins, 2002)

In its wild form, L. aphaca is a primary wild relative of Yellow Vetch, the cultivated form of the species. It is in the section Aphaca (Shehadeh et al. in prep) and following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 4 with the cultivated Grass Pea (L. sativus L.), Chickling Vetch (L. cicera L.), Sweet Pea (L. odoratus L.), Cyprus Vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea (L. latifolius L.), Caley Pea (L. hirsutus L.), and Spanish Vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

Lathyrus angulatus L. is a tertiary genetic relative of the cultivated Grass Pea, L. sativus L. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). It is in the section Linearicarpus (Shehadeh et al. in prep) and following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 4 of Chickling Vetch (L. cicera L.), Sweet Pea (L. odoratus L.), Cyprus Vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea (L. latifolius L.), Caley Pea (L. hirsutus L.), and Spanish Vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

Lathyrus hirsutus L. is cultivated in USA for animal food (forage and fodder) (Sarker et al. 2001), but only the wild populations are considered in this threat assessment. In its wild form, L. hirsutus is a primary wild relative of Caley Pea, the cultivated form of the species. According to Shehadeh et al. (in prep), it is a secondary genetic relative of the cultivated Grass Pea (L. sativus L.) although some sources state it is a tertiary genetic relative (Vincent et al. 2013. It is also a secondary genetic wild relative of Sweet Pea (L. odoratus L.) (Sarker et al. 2001). Lathyrus hirsutus is in the section Lathyrus (Shehadeh et al. in prep) and following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 2 of Chickling Vetch (L. cicera L.), and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea (L. latifolius L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep). It is also in Taxon Group 4 of Cyprus Vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Spanish Vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

Whilst at least in the west, C. demersum s.s. is so widespread and abundant that it is unlikely that taxonomic issues will affect its conservation or Red List assessment, inconsistent recording within the C. demersum complex is likely to affect the Red List assessments of any subordinate taxa assessed.

P. pusillus is a taxonomically difficult species. Difficulties of identification (particularly in the field) mean that distribution data are likely to include records that refer to the concept of P. berchtoldii employed here, as well as records of P. pusillus.

Wiegleb and Kaplan (1998) included P. berchtoldii within their concept of P. pusillus, although they have since accepted the separation of these two taxa. They state that "P. pusillus is regarded [..] as a highly polymorphic species with numerous regional forms and ecomorphoses. More detailed classification seems to be impossible because of the highly reticular variation. No correlated set of characters which would make discrimination of taxa possible have been confirmed". They also state that "Some of the plants called P. groenlandicus show certain characters deviant from the present concept of P. pusillus. They are characterized especially by the leaves with up 8 additional sclerenchymatous strands. These plants are known only from a geographically limited area in Western Greenland. Further research, such as experimental cultivation, is necessary in order to clarify its status."

The Flora of North America recognises three subspecies (Haynes and Barre-Hellquist 2000), while the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010) recognises only one at a global level.

Two hybrid combinations have been reported involving P. pusillus; P. perfoliatus × P. pusillus (P. × mysticus Morong) and P. pusillus × P. trichoides (P. × grovesii Dandy et G. Taylor), both are extremely rare and unlikely to affect either the survival of the species or this evaluation.

Subspecies schaferi, should be treated as a good species (N.P. Taylor and W. Barthlott pers. comms. 2010). This is further confirmed by the work of Korotkova (2011). For the purposes of this assessment, R. shaferi is included under R. baccifera.

Additional subspecies have been described in Africa and Madagascar but these are not recognized by Hunt et al. (2006).
Arias and Terrazas (2009) place this species in the genus Lophocereus.
Distinct species. "This is the giant of the genus", Benson.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. littoralis (K.Brandegee) N.P.Taylor. The  latter subspecies is considered by some experts to be a separate species and it is potentially Critically Endangered. The subspecies have not been assessed separately.

Sclerocactus glaucus is not treated here as a complex, and does not including S. brevispinus and S. wettlandicus.  Studies on population genetics and phylogeny of this group concluded these are different at the species rank (Heil and Porter 1994, Porter et al. 2000).
Texas Heritage questions the validity of this taxon.
There is controversy about the placement of Thelocactus setispunus under the genus Thelocactus. Given the morphological differences it would better be placed under Hamatocactus. Distinct species.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. fickeiseniorum (L.D.Benson) Lüthy.
Recognized as a full species by Kartesz (1999); has also been treated as a variety of Opuntia basilaris (e.g., by Kartesz 1994) or as a variety of O. erinacea.
Research is needed to determine its taxonomic status with respect to the P. royenii complex.
Echinomastus mariposensis is a synonym of the species.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. heilii Castetter, P.Pierce & K.H.Schwer. Following Hunt et al. (2006) subspecies heilii  includes S. cloverae K.D.Heil & J.M.Porter as a synonym. Other authors treat this as a good species, with subsp. heilii as a synonym (C. Butterworth, K. Heil and J. Porter pers. comms).

Heil and Porter's treatment of Pediocactus in the Flora of North America (Vol. 4, 2003) recognizes Pediocactus nigrispinus as a species, distinct from P. simpsonii. The text says, "Pediocactus nigrispinus has been referred to P. simpsonii var. robustior (J. M. Coulter) L. D. Benson, which remains well within the range of variation for P. simpsonii. An unpublished study by J. M. Porter et al. of noncoding chloroplast DNA sequences shows P. simpsonii is less closely related to P. nigripsinus than to P. knowltonii, P. winkleri, and P. despainii."
Kartesz's 1999 checklist includes Sclerocactus parvilorus ssp. terrae-canyonae which was treated as a separate species in the 1994 checklist.

Opuntia basilaris var. aurea of Kartesz (1994) treated as O. aurea by him in 1999 and is assessed separately as a good species.

Five varieties are currently recognized - the typical variety and O. b. brachyclada (Griffiths) Munz, O.b. heilii S.L.Welsh & Neese , O.b. longiareolata (Clover & Jotter) L.D.Benson, and O. b. treleasei (J.M. Coult.) J.M.Coult. ex Toumey  There may well be other varieties which should be recognized.

Five subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. bolaensis (Runge) Doweld, subsp., flavidispinus (Backeb.) N.P.Taylor, subsp. heterochromus  (F.A.C.Weber) Mosco & Zanov. and subsp. schwarzii (Backeb.) N.P.Taylor.
USFWS considered it a candidate in 1993 under the name Pediocactus papyracanthus.
Phylogenetic cytological and morphological work supports the circumscription of O. humifusa in a narrower sense than that recognized by Benson (1982).

According to Hunt et al. (2006) S. spinosior subsp. blainei  (S.L.Welsh & K.H.Thorne) Hochstätter should either be considered a separate species or S. pubispinus should also be included as a subspecies according to J. Porter and C. Butterworth (pers. comms.). However, the assessment is done including S. spinosior subsp. blainei .

The treatment followed in Kartesz (1999) excludes Sclerocactus sileri (formerly included in S. spinsior by Kartesz 1994); following this more narrow treatment, S. spinosior is endemic to Utah.

Hunt et al. (2006) treat P. desainii and P. winkleri as subspecies of P. bradyi, but these are widely accepted as being good species according to all North American floras and C.A. Butterworth (pers. comm.). They are considered separate species here.
A lot of confusion exists in the identification of this species and Opuntia phaeacantha.

Sclerocactus brevihamatus Engelm. was included in Sclerocactus scheeri by Kartesz (1994), but S. brevihamatus (Engelm) D.R.Hunt is recognized as a distinct species in Kartesz (1999). Two subspecies are recognized here, the nominate form and subsp. tobuschii (W.T.Marshall) N.P.Taylor.

Questionable nomenclature of the genus, Glandulicactus is more appropriate. Treated in genus Sclerocactus by Kartesz (1990); sometimes treated in Ancistrocactus.

Three subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. crassihamatus (F.A.C.Weber) N.P.Taylor and subsp. wrightii (Engelm.) N.P.Taylor .

Some authors treat this as a subspecies: Opuntia engelmannii subsp. aciculata (Griffiths) U.Guzmán & Mandujano, however, it is treated here as a good species following Hunt et al. (2006) and Pinkava 2003. The origin of this species is uncertain.

It is very likely that one of the varieties of the species will be reassigned as an element of S. johnsonii, this will radically reduce the extent of occurrence and population size of the species.

This species was previous listed as O. dillenii.

The type is not known (Britton & Rose 1919).

Hunt et al. (2006) treat this as an enigmatic taxon.
O. ammophila was described 1919 by J.K.Small and was placed in synonymy in O. humifusa by Benson (1982).  Work by Majure et al. in prep. supports the recognition of O. ammophila at the species level.
O. austrina was described 1903 by J.K.Small and was placed in synonymy in O. humifusa by Benson (1982).  Work by Majure et al. in prep. supports the recognition of O. austrina at the species level.
O. lata was described 1919 by J.K.Small and was placed in synonymy in O. humifusa by Benson (1982).  Work by Majure et al. in prep. supports the recognition of O. lata at the species level.
O. pollardii was described 1908 by J.K.Small and was placed in synonymy in O. humifusa by Benson (1982).  Work by Majure et al. in prep. supports the recognition of O. pollardii at the species level.
Digitaria nuda Schumach. is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).

Lathyrus japonicus Willd. is in the section Orobus (Shehadeh et al. in prep). Following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 4 of the cultivated Grass Pea (L. sativus L.), Chickling Vetch (L. cicera L.), Sweet Pea (L. odoratus L.), Cyprus Vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea (L. latifolius L.), Caley Pea (L. hirsutus L.), and Spanish Vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

Hess and Robins (2002) treat Yucca kanabensis as a variety of Yucca angustissima Engelm. ex Trel. but the fruits are markedly different. Also, Clary's (1997) molecular work supports recognizing Y. kanabensis (and Y. toftiae) as distinct from Y. angustissima. They note, however, that Welsh (2003) indicated significant intergradation among these taxa, making their recognition at varietal rank seem appropriate. However, recent work supports hybridisation events to be far more common than once thought, including hybridisation between capsular and baccate species (W. Hodgson pers. comm. 2018, SEINet 2018).

This taxon was not mentioned at all (including synonymy) in Flora of North America. Some botanists exclude it as simply an environmental dwarf form of Yucca harrimaniae, with which it differs not only by its much smaller, more dense rosette and smaller leaf size, but also its shorter inflorescence and pure white flowers (vs. cream to brownish; Hochstätter 2000). When grown in cultivation from seed or offsets with abundant water, this dwarf yucca retained its dense crowding of short, narrow leaves upon developing a slightly larger rosette (Hawker 2016). Lake Powell subpopulations may represent Yucca nana but require further investigation (Hochstätter 2000; Hawker 2016).
According to Justice (1988), many infraspecific ranks were reduced and only five are now considered varieties: diffusum, neomexicanum, torreyi, glabrum and douglasii.

There are recent taxonomic changes or current taxonomic doubts or debates about the validity or identity of Mockernut hickory (Carya tomentosa or Carya alba). Flora of North America (Stone 1997) identify this taxon as Carya tomentosa (Poir.) Nuttall. This report is based on the decision made by the Flora of North America editorial committee that Carya tomentosa should be its own species.

Kaul notes in FNA: "L. D. Benson (1943) reported intermediates between Platanus wrightii and P. racemosa in southern California. He reduced P. wrightii to P. racemosa var. wrightii (S. Watson) L. Benson. Most authors have retained that taxon at the specific level because of its more deeply lobed, more glabrate leaves and its often pedunculate fruiting heads. Very low yields of germinable seeds were obtained from crosses of P. wrightii and P. racemosa with P. occidentalis (F. S. Santamour Jr. 1972b)" (Kaul 2018).
According to Tropicos (2019) and The Plant List (2019), Cestrum elegans is an accepted name for this species.

The name of this species was published by David Douglas in 1835 following a specimen named by Bentham; the full scientific name should be therefore Lupinus nanus Douglas ex Benth (A. Planchuelo pers. comm. 2020). Because this name represents a polymorphic complex with large genetic variability, several subspecies and varieties have been described. After a taxonomic review it might be possible that some or almost all of them will not be recognized as distinct taxa. In addition, Dunn (1955) treated this species as part of the Lupinus micranthus complex of Mexico with several intercrosses and breeding mechanisms making their relationship obscure. Although the name is accepted, more research is need to clarified the status of all the infraspecific taxa and the relationship with other species (A. Planchuelo pers. comm. 2020).
Lupinus nanus is cultivated (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2020), but only wild populations will be considered in this threat assessment. In its wild form, L. nanus is a primary wild relative of Orean blue lupin, the cultivated form of the species.

Lathyrus palustris L. is in the section Orobus (Shehadeh et al. in prep) and following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is classified in Taxon Group 2 of Spring Vetch (L. vernus (L.) Bernh.) and in Taxon Group 4 with the cultivated Grass Pea (L. sativus L.), Chickling Vetch (L. cicera L.), Sweet Pea (L. odoratus L.), Cyprus Vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea (L. latifolius L.), Caley Pea (L. hirsutus L.), and Spanish Vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

There is some uncertainty about whether the two varieties of this species recognized by Freeman (1975) (Trillium chloropetalum var. chloropetalum and T.c. var. giganteum), are actually distinct species. Molecular data is necessary to resolve this relationship.
Phylogenetic analysis has recently placed this species within the genus Trillidium along with the formerly monotypic T. govanianum (Weakley et al 2018).

Allium triquetrum L. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the Allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Simpson (1988) considered that there are two subspecies in Africa. The subsp. schweinfurthiana (Boeck) D.A. Simpson is distributed from West Africa to Sudan and subsp. setifolia (A.Rich.) J. Raynal is more widespread. The former differs for the latter in the perianth bristles, which are at least half as long as the nutlet.

The nomenclature of this species is complicated. In Flora Iranica (Kukkonen 1998), the species F. littoralis Gaud. is accepted as a separate species from F. miliaceae (L.) Vahl. (Syn.: F. quinquangularis (Vahl) Kunth). In recent taxonomic treatments a wider sense of F. miliaea is accepted in which two other species are placed as its synonyms (e.g. Tropicos.org and in eFlora of N. America, and Amini Rad 2011).

Some taxonomic uncertainty has been noted owing to the type specimen for the species belonging to the closely related L. apiifolium (Applequist 2010, Brummitt 2011). It is likely that L. californicum is a synonym of L. apiifolium. Should the two be found to be conspecific, the Red List status would not be altered in either case.

Hooper and Napper (1972) suggested that Eleocharis subtilissima Nelmes, an aquatic plant, submerged apart from flowering stems, was very close to the Indian E. retroflexa. Following from this Haines and Lye (1983) considered E. subtilissima to be a subspecies of E. retroflexa (subspecies subtilissima (Nelmes). Probably this is an amphibious species. The aquatic form is named as E. subtilissima, while the terrestrial one is E. retroflexa (A. Mesterhazy pers. obs.)

This has been treated at times as a monospecific genus or a number of different species within the genus. It is extremely variable and many subordinate taxa have been described (e.g. TROPICOS lists 199 synonyms for this name). TROPICOS lists this taxon as P. communis Trin. by which name it was formerly known in the UK.


There is a degree of uncertainty over the taxonomic status of this species, some authorities consider that there is only species worldwide (e.g. T.A. Cope pers. comm.), however, a number of taxa are generally recognized (e.g. The Plant List). As a consequence of this uncertainty, it is very difficult to establish the true distribution of the various taxa. This assessment uses a combination of the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families and the Invasive Species Compendium (CABI International) to derive a country list, however, it is not certain that this list is comprehensive.

This species can be regarded as the tropical counterpart of Phragmites australis; as noted by Cope (1982) (Cope, T.A. 1982 Flora of Pakistan No. 143. Poaceae. Jointly published by the Institute of Plant Conservation, University of Karachi and Missouri Botanical Press) "for most of their range these two species of Phragmites are allopatric. Phragmites australis is a temperate species while Phragmites karka is tropical". However, different approaches to recognition of taxa within the genus and uncertainty about taxonomy in some areas make it difficult to establish the precise distribution and status of this taxon.

Hibiscus tiliaceus is a widespread and well-known tropical and subtropical coastal species. Variety tiliaceaus is largely Old World occurring on the shores of the Indian Ocean and around much of the Pacific Basin whereas variety pernambucucensis is a New World variant occurring on both the Atlantic and Pacific shores of the American tropics. A small group of additional species, each of more limited distribution are centred taxonomically around these two taxa forming a natural group. This group is sometimes treated as a section within Hibiscus or separately from Hibiscus under a different genus (e.g. as Talipariti following Fryxell 2001). Sometimes the species are lumped into one or a few species. This group is kept under a broad concept of Hibiscus following Pfeil and Crisp (2005).
A very large number of synonyms and infrataxa have been described for this widespread species.

From 1976 until 1983, nomenclatural confusion designated Paspalum distichum for P. vaginatum and Paspalum paspaloides for P. distichum (Schulz 1962, Guedes 1976, 1981; Fosberg 1977, Renvoize and Clayton 1980). The matter was resolved in 1983 (Brummitt 1983) and appropriate taxonomic and morphological distinctions can be found in Echarte and Clausen (1993) and Webster (1987).

The main difference between the two species is that P. vaginatum inherently colonizes saline ecosystems while P. distichum can be found in freshwater habitats. Genetically, they are quite distinct (Echarte and Clausen 1993), and the two species can be differentiated by 20 morphological traits [adapted from Duncan 1997].

Some authorities recognize Trillium parviflorum as a subspecies of T. albidum (T. a. J.D. Freeman ssp. parviflorum (Soukup) K.L. Chambers & S.C. Meyers) (USDA, NRCS 2019). This assessment treats T. parviflorum at the species level. Should the two species be lumped, the status of T. albidum would likely not change, though T. parviflorum would.

British literature often refers to this species as Trillium nervosum (Flora of North America (FNA) Editorial Committee 2002).
Recent work by Susan Farmer is likely to result in the division of this species into two taxa encompassing the northern and a southern portions of the species' range. It remains to be seen if this division will result in a species level designation or a variety level distinction.
This species is likely to be consolidated with T. underwoodii in the near future. As T. underwoodii is the older name, T. decipiens will be relegated to synonym status.

Trillium tennesseense E.E. Schill. & Floden is a validly published species but is included here as a synonym because the taxon is not recognized by FNA, Kew, USDA, or ITIS. Should the taxon be recognized at the species level, it would qualify for listing as Critically Endangered under criteria B1ab(iii,iv,v).
Recent genetic research has identified five distinct, but morphologically indistinguishable, lineages within the currently recognized species. Two of these lineages will be named in 2020 and may be elevated to the species level. This change is likely to result in changes to the conservation status of the resulting taxa.
The species has historically been misidentified as a host of other species including T. ludovicianum, T. sessile, and T. viride (Freeman 1975).

Trillium parviflorum was maintained as a distinct species by Flora of North America Editorial Committee (2002). Chambers and Meyers (2011) published the treatment of this taxon as a subspecies of Trillium albidum: "It is appropriate to recognize this pattern of north-to-south intergradation between the two taxa." "The results of a study by Bledsoe (1993) are best interpreted by making T. parviflorum a subspecies of T. albidum. A clinal relationship in morphology was shown to exist between the former entity (whose type locality is Ft. Lewis, Pierce County, Washington) and the latter (type locality near Selma, Josephine County, Oregon), with populations in the Willamette Valley, from Polk and Marion counties to at least as far south as Sutherlin, Douglas County, exhibiting a mixture of vegetative and floral traits of the two nominal extremes." (Chambers and Meyers 2011).

Trillium texanum and Trillium georgianum are often described as varieties of T. pusillum. This account examines the Trillium pusillum complex separate from the widely recognized T. georgianum and T. texanum which are treated at the species level elsewhere.

It is very likely that future taxonomic work will divide T. pusillum into eight distinct species (T. alabamicum, T. carolinianum, T. monticola, T. ozarkanum, T. palustris, T. pusillum, T. telmacola, and T. virginianum). Each of these putative species is considered separately within this assessment. Though T. pusillum is listed as Least Concern whether or not these putative species are included, serious conservation concerns exist for subpopulations currently recognized as T. pusillum and listing as Least Concern should not imply that conservation actions are not currently needed to protect the species complex.

The taxonomic concept of T. simile has changed over time and is likely to become increasingly restricted in the future. The species has distinctive smell based on subpopulation which may reflect underlying taxonomic distinctions. Future revisions may result in the species becoming a North Carolina endemic.

Trillium underwoodii is likely to subsume Trillium decipiens in a taxonomic change. As both species are likely considered Least Concern, taxonomic changes are unlikely to result in changes to the conservation status of either species.

Perrottetia wichmaniorum is similar to P. sandwicensis from which it differs by its larger, thicker, more pubescent and rugose leaves with a smaller length:width ratio [1.5–1.7:1], larger inflorescences with usually four degrees of branching with moderately to densely hirtellous axes, the staminate inflorescences 12.5–14 cm long, 10–13 cm wide, the pistillate inflorescences 9–13 cm long, 6–13 cm wide, and flowers of both sexes with glabrous petals.

Porlieria angustifolia is treated here as the accepted taxon name where Guaiacum angustifolium is treated as a homotypic synonym. Some of the data used in this assessment comes from literature using the name of Guaiacum angustifolium.

Perilla frutescens (L.) Britton has three accepted varieties: var. frutescens; var. crispa (Thunb.) H.Deane; var. hirtella (Nakai) Makino (Board of Trustees, RBG Kew 2019). Ocimum frutescens L. is the basionym for this species (WCSP 2019).

Prunus eremophila was recently described in 2002 from San Bernardino County, California. It is endemic to California and is distinguished from P. havordii, a close relative, by its leaf-pubescence and larger petal and fruit size (Prigge 2002).
Distinct species.

There are no significant taxonomic issues affecting this name. Two subspecies are recognised by the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010): subsp. tenuifolius (Raf.) Hultén, which occurs in central and far-eastern Russia, Mongolia and Japan, and subsp. alpinus occurs throughout the rest of the species rang and appears to overlap with subsp. tenuifolius throughout much of the range of the latter.

P. alpinus is known to hybridise with P. crispus L. (P. ×olivaceus Baagöe ex G. Fisch.), P. gramineus L. (P. ×nericius Hagstr.), P. lucens L. (P. ×nerviger Wolfg. in Schult. et Schult.), P. perfoliatus L. (P. ×prussicus Hagstr.), P. polygonifolius Pourr. (P. ×spathulatus Schrad. ex W. D. J. Koch et Ziz,) and P. praelongus Wulfen (P. ×griffithii A. Benn.). None of these hybrids are frequent and they are unlikely to represent a threat to the species.

Yucca brevifolia is arborescent with a distinct trunk and stout branches, while Y. jaegeriana is generally smaller with somewhat smaller branches arising from the base. Yucca brevifolia  has monopodial branching while those of Y. jaegeriana has a dichotomous branching pattern (Rowlands 1978, Lenz 2007). Yucca brevifolia  has longer leaves (15-35 cm vs. 10-20 cm).  Flowers of Y. brevifolia are globular, those of Y. jaegeriana are narrowly campanulate; fruits and pollinators are different.

There are probably cryptic taxa within the H. whipplei complex. In addition, further field work in the Vizcaíno region of Baja is warranted to verify specimen identification (W. Hodgson pers. comm. 2019).
Falcataria falcata has several changes in nomenclature and was previously placed in the genus Paraserianthes, Adenanthera and Albizia.
Considered by Euro+Med (2019) to be a synonym of Crataegus chlorocarpa Lenné & K.Koch.

This species is conformed by two varieties, Capsicum annuum var. annuum which is the cultivated form and C. annuum var. glabriusculum which is the wild form. We are here assessing the later variety.

Capsicum annuum L. var. glabriusculum (Dunal) Heiser & Pickersgill is a primary wild relative of bell/chili pepper, C. annuum var. annuum (of which it is the progenitor), and Tabasco pepper, C. frutescens L., a secondary wild relative of aji, C. baccatum L. var. pendulum (Willd.) Eshbaug, and a tertiary wild relative of rocoto, C. pubescens Ruiz & Pav. Habanero pepper (Capsicum chinense) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

Species keys require flowering material to accurately distinguish Lobelia villosa (Rock) H. St. John & Hosaka and Lobelia wahiawa Lammers and there is very little herbarium material available as the plants are not often found flowering. Here Lobelia wahiawa Lammers is treated as the plants with glabrous inflorescence found around Wahiawa and the main ridge to the north along Kauai’s wet windward slopes. Also occasionally occurring around southeast Alaka`i’s Wai`ale`ale and Kawaikini region; Lobelia villosa (Rock) H. St. John & Hosaka are represented by pubescent inflorescence of varying degrees that occur around the entire Alaka`i (mostly bogs) and runs into the high elevation wind swept ridges of northern Kaua`i.
