Physalis cordata Houst. ex Mill. is a wild relative of Cape gooseberry, P. peruviana L., low ground-cherry, P. pubescens L. and tomatillo, P. philadelphica Lam. The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

Physalis pubescens L. is a secondary wild relative of Cape gooseberry, P. peruviana L., and in its wild form is a primary wild relative of low ground-cherry, the cultivated form of the species (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

Cucurbita digitata A. Gray is a tertiary wild relative of cushaw (C. argyrosperma C. Huber ssp. argyrosperma), fig-leaf gourd (C. ficifolia Bouche), maxima pumpkin/squash (C. maxima Duchesne), moschata pumpkin/squash (C. moschata Duchesne) and pepo pumpkin/squash (C. pepo L.) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Solanum stoloniferum is a secondary wild relative of potato, S. tuberosum L. ssp. tuberosum (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Tripsacum lanceolatum Rupr. ex E. Fourn. is a tertiary wild relative of maize (Z. mays L. ssp. mays) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

The Celtis subgenus Mertensia was revised and the former Celtis punctata (Urb. & Ekman) Urb. & Ekman was placed in synonymy under C. ehrenbergiana (Klotzsch) Liebm. (Berg and Dahlberg 2001). Tropicos (2020) lists 57 synonyms for Celtis ehrenbergiana. Liogier (1996) and Acevedo and Strong (2012) recognize Celtis punctata as a separate species endemic to Hispaniola. However, given the revision of the genus, C. ehrenbergiana, as revised is now considered to be widely distributed in southern US, Mexico, Hispaniola, Puerto Rico and South America.

Gossypium thurberi Tod. is a tertiary wild relative of Cotton (G. hirsutum L.), Sea Island Cotton (G. barbadense L.), Short-staple Cotton (G. herbaceum L.) and Tree Cotton (G. arboretum L.) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

The species bears a commemorative epithet to botanist, Clara Hunt. The historical spelling of the specific epithet, clarianus, has been identified as incorrect and, accordingly, corrected to claranus (Silva 1998). Astragalus clarianus is therefore an orthographical variant of Astragalus claranus (Rogers 2015) and this spelling has been commonly applied in literature around the species historically (Barneby 1964, Liston 1992, USFWS 1997).

Dispute exists around the taxonomic status of all species within the genus Echinacea. Echinacea laevigata is accepted at the species level by the taxonomic revision proposed by Binns et al. (2002) and is likely to remain valid at the species level.

Yucca harrimaniae is an extremely diverse taxon, especially in vegetative characteristics. Several taxa have been reduced to synonymy under Y. harrimaniae: Y. harrimaniae ssp. sterilis (Neese & Welsh) Hochstätter, Y. nana Hochstätter, Y. gilbertiana Trelease, and Y. neomexicana. Hess and Robbins (2002) note that McKelvey (1947) included Yucca neomexicana in Y. harrimaniae, as did Reveal (1977), who gave it varietal status. DNA studies indicate that Y. harrimaniae and Y. neomexicana are discrete and not closely related species (Clary 1997). In addition to the DNA evidence, these taxa are allopatric, separated by the San Juan Mountains of Colorado, providing further support for recognising them as separate species (Hess and Robbins 2002). Recognition of  the morphologically dissimilar Y. harrimaniae ssp. sterilis, Y. nana, and Y. gilbertiana may be warranted (Hochstätter 2000, Hawker 2016). Like so many yucca taxa, this species complex is in need of further systematic study. Given that most yucca months are obligate pollinators, identification of the moth pollinators may also provide insight into the taxonomic status of these yuccas.

According to Hess and Robbins (2002), McKelvey (1938, 1947) suggested that Yucca utahensis is most closely related to Y. elata, from which it differs primarily in growth habit, capsule size, and leaf width, although with overlaps. Welsh et al. (2003) considered it equally or more closely related to Y. angustissima var. kanabensis, but DNA evidence (Clary 1997) suggests a closer relationship with Y. elata. Webber (1953) believed that Y. utahensis is a hybrid between Y. elataand Y. angustissima. The plants that are caulescent or subcaulescent were recognized by Reveal (1977) as Y. elata var. utahensis; those that are acaulescent, or infrequently caulescent and with racemose inflorescences, were included in Y. angustissima. Within a given subpopulation of Y. elata, Y. angustissima and Y. utahensisone there is variability with regards to caulescent vs. acaulescent habit and racemose vs. paniculate inflorescences, particularly as one travels further away from each species’ centre of distribution (W. Hodgson, pers. comm. 2018, SEINet 2018).  Subpopulations within all of Grand Canyon range form tall, caulescent tree forms to more commonly smaller caulescent to acaulescent forms with primarily paniculate, but sometimes racemose inflorescences or inflorescences paniculate below and racemose above. They appear most similar to Y. utahensis, but additional research, including molecular study, is required.
D. Pinkava (pers. comm.) purports that this species has all the characters of a hybrid; it is closely related to C. alcahes.

Hunt et al. (2006) listed H. aboriginum Small ex Britton & Rose, H. fragrans Small ex Britton & Rose, H. divaricata (Lam.) Backeb., H. taylorii Britton, H. portoricensis Britton and H. simpsonii Small ex Britton & Roseas synonyms of H. gracilis. Most regional assessments treat these as distinct taxa. However, until the results of the current taxonomic analyses that are underway are published, H. gracilis is assessed as a single species complex. Future re-assessments are recommended to take into consideration these circumstances.
Cylindropuntia fulgida is a synonym of Opuntia fulgida.

This species (Delissea undulata) was known from two varieties: D. undulata var. undulata and D. u. var. argutidentata. The variety from Hawai'i Island was elevated to D. argutidentata and the variety from Maui was elevated to D. undulata.

Yucca torreyi Shafer has been considered a synonym of Yucca treculeana Carriere by several authors: Hess and Robbins 2002  and Thiede 2020. In this assessment we follow Clary and Simpson (1995) and Clary (1997), who consider Yucca torreyi as an accepted species based on molecular and morphological data.
Arenaria livermorensis, as accepted in Kartesz (1994), is also accepted in Kartesz (1999) and FNA (Vol. 5, 2005).
This species can be distinguished by its consistently monocarpic habit, single rosette growth, and inconspicuous placental wings on the fruit.

Yucca glauca and Y. arkansana are very similar. The leaves of Y. glauca are uniform in size, rigid, linear or linear-lanceolate, and up to 1.2 cm wide. In Y. arkansana, the young leaves immediately surrounding the peduncle are distinctly shorter than the outer leaves of the rosette, and mature leaves are generally somewhat flexible, lanceolate, and up to 2.5 cm wide. (FNA) K. H. Clary’s (1997) DNA evidence does not indicate as close a relationship as the morphological characters suggest. J. M. Webber (1953) believed that Y. glauca forms hybrids with Y. baileyi, Y. elata, Y. constricta, and Y. angustissima.
